reviewText:
It's everything we love about Star Wars
I consider Jedi Outcast one of the best narrative Star Wars games ever. It's a simple and straightforward story, driven by the most classic of action hero motivations: revenge. It's a fine line to walk for our Jedi protagonist, Kyle Katarn. But he's no Luke Skywalker. From blasters, grenades, mines and more, no weapon goes left unused by Katarn in his quest for answers. And yes, that includes lightsabers.

In fact, the Jedi Knight series still possesses the best lightsaber combat to date. Every swing, every thrust has the potential to be deadly, whether it's your lightsaber or your enemy's. No florescent batons here: swings cut through enemies neatly and quickly, as they should. Enable the dismemberment option for increased pandemonium.

The greatest con might be the series' age. The visuals definitely diminished with time. But see if that still matters when the game hands you a lightsaber, a room full of Storm Troopers, and John William's score begins swelling.

Oh, and did I mention they got Billy Dee Williams back to voice Lando? Because they got Billy Dee back to voice Lando. Awesome.

reviewText:
Oh boy, here we go:

I would just like to point out that I don't write reviews, no matter how good a game is besides this one (It's that good).

It was my first multiplayer game which I grew up with and met awesome people that I talk to till this day.

Singleplayer and multiplayer are both awesome even without the option of dual lightsabers and staff (I'm looking at you JKA) which is the reason why it seems so off puting for most people.It's sequel puts this game to shame in my opinion because it simply didn't have any substance. I will stop myself before I go too deep into the other game before it's too late.

Once you get tired of singleplayer you can then spawn a bunch of rebel and imperial armies and spectate the massacre or you may attempt to take on a reborn army by yourself while having the maximum gore, matrix spin command and god mode enabled. I assure you it will keep you entertained.

After that it's time to behold the divine radiance of the most angry, most unpleasant and most frag hungry community that dwells in the jk2 multiplayer. That is ofcourse, if you're playing the 1.02 version of the game. Other versions of the game feel and act as singleplayer while the 1.02 version is like combining quake and soul calibour but without a insane amounts possible combos you can perform. Multiplayer takes some time to get used to but it's worth it (tryhard intensifies).

JK2 was praised for the way you used your force powers, you actually felt like a real jedi and it was awesome. Visuals aren't too impressive since it has aged a bit (2002).The story in singleplayer was decent but nothing too intriguing, also the weapons were fun to use but ofcourse once you get your lightsaber back you don't want to use guns again. You progress through singleplayer in a typical fashion, and aquire a new force power after you complete each level. Level design was good but it didn't vary as much as I hoped it would.

The game is easy to mod and gives you even more stuff to have fun with. Mapping isn't too hard as well, it all depends how much ambition you have. You can also download a ridicilous amounts of mods for both singleplayer and multiplayer for even more fun. A HD remake of this game would mean serious cash for Lucas ar- I mean Disney.

Unfortunately my review can't even give a close enough impression on exactly how devine this game is, 10/10 best game I have ever played, there's a special place in my heart for this game.

P.S: If you need any help with the multiplayer, patching or anything related to the game I will do everything in my power to help you if you ask nicely.

We don't make games as we used to anymore.

reviewText:
I'm sure this game was amazing at the time of release. You actually get to play as a Jedi with a lightsaber! And it's not just a click-to-melee-attack weapon, you can control the direction of the swing and stuff! The lightsaber combat would have been something new and innovative at the time.

Unfortunately, once again I've ended up playing a sequel before a previous installment. I played Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy already. I thought I'd done right this time, I mean, come on! That one is called Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy, this one is called Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.

With that polished experience in mind, I found Outcast's lightsaber combat frustrating. I know how to use the lightsaber but time and time again I found myself getting sliced to pieces. The Reborn and the Dark Jedi are able to perform rapid and intricate slash maneuvers that you just cannot.

Speaking of frustrating, this game has some of the worst level design I've ever seen. I don't like it when games insist on holding my hand the whole time with large waypoint markers on linear maps but Jedi Outcast really went all the way in the other direction. Almost every mission found me stuck at some point because I simply couldn't figure out where to go next. Sometimes the place you're supposed to go next would turn out to be a tiny grate IN THE CEILING in a non-descript room that you'd already passed through earlier in the level. Sometimes it's an inconspicuous hole that's off to the side of the path, but the path continues for several more encounters with no indication so you wind up fighting through one or two more entire map sections before finally ending up in a place with walls you can't climb and doors that don't open, wondering if there's a switch that you missed somewhere.

Ending this on a high note, the plot was good and the sounds of the Star Wars universe are always a pleasure to listen to. The music, the beeps and whirs of panels, even the sound of blaster fire, it's great.

reviewText:
I've compleated more than 10 playthoroughs of this game when I was about 15 and Star Wars were becoming cool again. More than 12 years later this game made me feel sorry about next-hen gaming, which will never give me this kind of fun and involvement. Everything about this game has aged quite a bit, but the core gameplay is timeless. Everything that you might consider as a flaw today is somehow balanced by something else, that is just unbeatable about this game:
- graphics is old - but you get to be a cool jedi with lightsaber and various force powers
- dialogs are aged and acting is so-so - but original SW music makes you feel great
- cutscenes are by all means outdated - but the story is timeless
Played this game as a kid and I loved it. I played it as adult, and I love it even more. I wish there were more games like this one.

reviewText:
Having put over 75 hours into this game, it's about time i reviewed it.  Don't expect much from me though, as i've never reviewed anything before.

Firstly, it's big, and it's beautiful.  Yes, the graphics are dated, and can't compete at all in regards to most games nowadays, but, if like me, you regard graphics secondary to gameplay, then you wont be the least bit disappointed, because they still look great.  At the risk of sounding sacreligious; i'm not that big of a Star Wars fan, so if you aren't either, don't worry...the way this game is executed, even if it had no Star Wars Related themes, it would still tower over many other Action / FPS games.


To sum it up:

Great dialogue throughout; keeping the story moving, interesting, and consistent.

So much to do, so so much!  It's not the most challenging game out there, but there's barely any 'grinding'...the pace remains throughout, and some of the challenges will force you to engage your mind more than you would expect.

But most importantly!  It's fun, and interesting.

reviewText:
This is one of the greatest Star Wars games in the whole entire world. This game introduced me to Star Wars back in 2002 as a child and my love of star wars began with this game (not with the movies).

12 years on and this game is still brilliant, it has one of the greatest single-player stories I have ever encountered with Star Wars games (and one of the most fun as well). It also has cool cinematics! And the voice of Billy Dee Williams (Lando from the movies)!

It also has brilliant multi-player, the game types are fun, the maps are cool and the gameplay is excellent. Despite whether you are playing with bots, or other humans multi-player will still be fun.



Also, when you wield your lightsaber and stick your lightsaber into the wall (or another person), orange lightsaber marks will form. This is one of the only Star Wars games I know to actually have this feature. Quite cool, especially for a 12 year old game. :)

reviewText:
I got a ton of Star Wars related games at the Winter Steam Sale, and oh boy I was glad this one was one of them. Now, I'll do my best so my love for this game doesn't hide it's problems, and I will start right off with them, as usual:

The biggest problem this game has, is that it was NOT build for computers of this generation. The resolution is not the only problem you'll have to face, but there are also glitches, such as strange shadows and even (at least on my case), strange brightness errors, as I everthing was strangely bright and I had to lower it, making me see it right, but all screenshots show the game to be really dark. If you want to play the game, have patience and look for guides arround the Internet on how to get over these problems.

The second problem it has, and really the only other I have, are the difficulty spikes. There are areas of the game that don't f#ck arround. Take Nar Shadda (did I type that right?) as an example, a huge map FILLED WITH SNIPERS, which can easily 1-Hit kill you with barely any time to react... And yet you're supposed to do all kinds of platforming arround it, on which missing a platform will kill you. There are other examples, such as your first encounter with the shadow sith jedi guys, which are WAY MORE POWERFUL AND TOUGH than any other Reborn you've faced so far (even more than the boss before that), and you're supposed to take on two at the same time. Even with all of your powers later on, just one of these guys might get tricky, just get the idea. The game ain't a walk in the park, and you should expect it to be a tough journey.

However, is the game good if we look away from those two problems? You bet your motherf#cking â™¥â™¥â™¥. The game is a sequel on the Jedi Knight series of games, and follows up Kyle Katarn's adventures, but it ain't really needed that you play the previous games to understand it. However, you might need a bit of knowledge about Star Wars to understand most of it. It starts as a classic FPS with tons of enemies, no regenerative health, armor (or shields, in this case), and a ton of enemies who are pathetic and weak in comparison with you. However, the game changes itself mid-way, as soon enough you have a light-saber and can use the power of the force, AND THAT'S WHEN THE GAME TRULY GOES FROM GOOD TO F#CKING GREAT. Light-saber combat on this game is insanely fun to pull-off, specially against other Light-saber users.

The force also feels natural on the game, neither being useless or broken: just like in the movies, it's a tool. You can push stuff, pull stuff, slow-down the game, mind-trick people like old Ben Kenobi did on the movies, a ton of cool stuff. There are a lot of powers in the game, and you unlock them as you go through it. Some enemies also use them, and eventually you'll find a use to most of them on your play-style.

The story and the characters also feel great. I won't spoil much more (I did spoil that you get a light-saber, BUT COME ON, KYLE HAS IT ON NEARLY ALL THE ADDS OF THE GAME ANYWAY!), but the only thing I didn't like about them is that Lando doesn't appear nearly enough, and characters such as Han Solo would have also been great. Oh, and the game goes after Episode VI and before the new one.

The multiplayer was fun, also. And I say was" and not "is"

This game is old. It doesn't have the best graphics. Therefor you can enjoy the story of Kyle Katarn and the usage of a lightsaber. For Star Wars Fans this is a must anyway but also guys who are interested in lightsaber fighting shouldn't miss this game!

reviewText:
When comparing Jedi Outcast to fellow contemporary titles. There has yet to be a game that blends design and functionality to such a startling degree.

You follow Kyle Katarn, returned to a jaded mercenary after the events of the last game. After a few routine levels you are immediately thrust onto a revenge odyssey across the galaxy. Going from isolated outposts in the middle of nowhere, to Cloud City, to the sprawling nest of Nar Shadda. The game keeps a good pace and it has an extraordinary lightsaber combat system.

That's nothing to say about the multiplayer and the modding community this game had, at it's height it was immensly popular and customizeable. You could play this game however you wanted, and with a great community of players.

The only other real contender Outcast has for greatest Star Wars game is most likely it's sequel Jedi Academy.

reviewText: Ever wanted a game that made you feel like you are a Jedi, complete with all the amazing force powers? Then look no further than Jedi Knight 2. The lightsaber combat is amazing (even allowing in-game cheats that make all lightsabers realistic to the movies), you have some amazing force powers at your disposal (Grip, Lightning, Mind Trick), and the game is just fun to play (looking at you, Force Unleashed!). The game also supports a multiplayer that is still very active, and also has AI bots for those who don't want to play with others. In conclusion, if you want a fun Star Wars game (made by the same people who made the X-Men: Origins Wolverine game) Jedi Knight 2 is the game for you.\n

reviewText:
Probably my best Action Star Wars game.

What to love:
+ Kick â™¥â™¥â™¥ sword fighting
+ Nice level designs that mixes discovery, platforming and action together.
+ Force powers with every new level
+ Various Star Wars locations
+ Community mods

What to hate:
- The Nar Shaddaa level has ridicolous snipers
- If you are unfamiliar with classic FPS games and your first FPS games were Call of Duty 4 (and onward) then you may hate this game because it has no location pointer, no health regenration, complex level design, and lots of situation where you are basically out numbered.

While this continue after JK1 events, I think you could play it and enjoy its plot. The plot is not complicated anyways and it is enough if you just watched the old trilogy (Ep 4,5,6).

Disclaimer: I am a huge Star Wars fan, and have played this game a lot as a child/teenager, so as my foot note points out (see the bottom of my review pages), this review may be biased.

Title Information
Review Title        Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast                Review Date        10th of March 2016                PC Release Date        26th of March 2002                Developer        Raven Software                Publisher        LucasArts                Genre        1st & 3rd Person Shooter/Action Adventure                Series        Dark Forces (3rd in the Series)                Single Player        Yes                Multiplayer        Yes
Ratings

Devo's Seal of Approval?:
Totally! I am signing, sealing, and delivering this title to you as a must play. This entry in the Dark Forces Series takes the mantle from its predecessors and makes it 10 feet taller. This title makes me yearn for a modern, force user centric 1st person shooter set in the Star Wars universe - a yearning which was not quite quenched with the re-release of Battlefront in 2015.

PROS
The solid and ground breaking gameplay from Dark Forces & Dark Forces II is back,
Streamlined user interface which is easy to navigate,
Amazing lightsaber combat with subtle, yet strong features including stance variation,
Improved character movement including acrobatic features,
Familiar and iconic enemies with interesting new additions,
Excellent new weapons,
Addition of a slow-motion action- and death-sequence camera,
Great graphics with amazing attention to detail (rain drops hitting your lightsaber make it sizzle"!)

reviewText: This is one of the best Star Wars games. I've played it through again just few weeks ago so my opinion is not based on nostalgia. While Jedi Academy adds lightsaber moves and is newer this one has better story (not anything amazing but it mostly makes sense and that's more than what I can say about most recent games) and makes you appreciate weapons other than the lightsaber. The puzzles are a mixed bag, most are good but there are some that will make you run in circles (although usually you just need to look up to solve them). Jedi Outcast's strongest point is undoubtedly combat - a mix of classic FPS and great lightsaber/force system. Some powers/weapons are obviously better than the others but on Padawan difficulty level you can pretty much play around as you like. And play around you can! Force Pull stormtrooper's rifle from his hands and watch as he runs away in panic! Grab one enemy with Force Choke and shield yourself from his friends fire! Finally, I recommend playing with a certain cheat code activated - g_saberRealisticCombat 1 - It allows you to cut apart enemies a lot more than the base game (although it's a bit buggy and results in beheaded characters screaming and other weirdness. Nothing gamebreaking though). Word of warning - it makes the game both easier and harder since it makes some hit zones an instant kill (for both player and npcs). It causes shorter, more frantic duels with Dark Jedi and can end the final battle in seconds (which is hilarious when it happens). Overall I rate the game 8.5/10 (-1,5 for all the annoyances along the way). It's not a perfect game but still loads of fun and worth it's price.

reviewText:
A classic, is amongst my favorite games. The game has amazing lightsaber combat, some of the best sword style combat on any platform.
Jedi Outcast has great shooting mechanics as well as easy access Force powers.
Being the game came out in 2003, it takes influence from many sources. It contains elements of influence from the matrix, force jump allows you to run up walls, and force speed slows all projectiles around you. The game even has the unreal Flak Cannon (called the flechette gun).

The game has an interesting online community with more than just your standard death match fare. It has a different rule set with players often taking time to duel rather than straight openly murder each other (Though some servers have different rules and contain straight death match)
It's worth taking note you can turn off your lightsaber with the 1 button, often players find the saber turned state as you being hostile.

For the cheap price of 10 bucks this game is worth it, I've spent easily over 400 hours on it. (Not the steam version but when I owned the disc)

All joking aside about my childhood, this game is so fun and for only 10 dollars it is a steal. Just buy it. Be warned though because the game seems deceptively easy at first, but there are probably hundreds of instant death zones in the game. Play through on padawan first to get a feel for the controls as there is a learning curve (can you imagine a game this old still has a learning curve? a testament to its greatness), and then play through on the difficulty of your chosing and become a jedi!.

reviewText:
To begin with: I recommend you to buy this game, it's more then worth it.

Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast is a game in the series of Dark Forces and Jedi Knight. In my opinion it is the best game in the whole series (some may disagree) because it contains a very nice single player and and very good (and well balanced) multiplayer.

Singeplayer: The SP is set after the collapse of the empire. The ex-Jedi Knight Kyle Katarn is working as a mercenary for the new formed republic, trying to find outposts of the Remnant troops of the empire, who still work against the republic. In the process of the singleplayer Katarn regains his jedi power and discovers the real aims of the imperial troops. The story telling is very well embeded in the normal game flow, which is a good mix of action (fighting with weapons, lightsabers, force) and thinking (solving puzzles, finding ways). There is an option to set the level of difficulty, so the game is demanding, no matter how good or bad you are.

Multiplayer: After the SP (which is quite long), you may want to play MP. The general MP is very similiar to other Quake3-Games: You have Gametypes like Deathmatch, TD, CTF etc. But there are also some special gamemodes like JediMaster (one player is the jedimaster with every force power, the rest just owns weapons and has to kill him), CTY (like CTF but the flag-stealer isnt allowed to use force), Holocron (the force powers are spreaded at the maps in little boxes which you can pick up).  After you joined a MP server you'll have to set your name, your skin and your force powers, where you can choose either the dark or light side and disturb force points in the different powers (like lightning, absorbation, healing, jump, speed). Note that there servers which disable weapons or forces, leaving you with nothing more than your saber ;)
The MP experience itself is unique - you can have normal deathmatches there, but also nice chats or exciting light saber duels; the lightsaber fight is the best I have ever seen in a Star Wars game: you can choose your style (fast, medium, slow means: less, normal, many damage per hit) and the saber reacts to every mouseclick you do, so with a bit of training you can do really nice combos. Also, back then, the modding community was quite active, giving you access to dozens of very good maps, tools and server mods.

Sooo all in all - buy the game, you'll not regret it :D
ps: I know Steam shows 0 hours on record, thats because my old JK wasnt linked with steam - my real play time lies anywhere among 500 and 1000 hours.
pss: ooh and sorry for my english, this isn't my main language.

reviewText:
Probably one of THE best STAR WARS games out there. Full of action, full of fun, features Kyle Katarn (my childhood hero), and the most realised lightsaber combat in any of the STAR WARS titles so far. Dismemberment (with cheats for more!), full contact lightsaber fighting. Think Chivalry with a lightsaber if you play in any one of the hundreds of ARENA map mods. Multiplayer plays a lot like Quake, being fast paced, force-powered fun.

Play this, then play Academy. Then play this again.

Loved it on the Gamecube. Loved it even more on PC. Large modding community, and the potential for months and  months of epic lightsaber combat.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast excels in an area no other game has remotely succeeded: real-time lightsabre combat.

JK2:JO affords players the opportunity to try various lightsabre forms, and perform unique attack in those forms based upon the ways you move your character in the game world. Complete with blocks, combos, parries and lightsabre duels, Outcast is the definitive lightsabre experience in the very long history of Star Wars titles.

Surprisingly, the game is equally good. With a very engaging single player campaign, not to mention riotously fun multiplay, this deserves to be in the collection of every gamer who ever called themselves a Star Wars fan.

reviewText:
Star wars - Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast			* 9/10
Definitely one of My favourite games, and my favourite Jedi Knight Chapter.

Jedi Knight 2 is the following chapter and takes place about two years after Mysteries of The Sith. Kyle abandoned both the force and his lightsaber after the incident at the end of the MotS and now works with Jan Ors on some missions for the Republic. Mon Mothma, Leader of the New Republic, sent them to a remnant base because of an intercepted communication citing the valley of the jedi and a rebirth. They will discover some experiments, and after an ambush Kyle will be forced to re-establish his connection with the force and get back his lightsaber in order to retaliate against the remnants.
I know it might sound dull but I'm trying to keep the most important details because I would spoil the best parts of the story, which is very important in this chapter, as it's very well studied. And during our journey we'll meet very well known character as Lando And Luke Dubbed by Billy Dee Williams and Mark Hamill Themselves.

The gameplay follows the classic structure of the previous chapters but it's more polished and has lots of innovations that make this chapter the best. You start the game without lightsaber or force powers as in Dark Forces 2, so you will use blasters and weapons. There will be some old classics, such as Kyle's blaster pistol, the wookie bowcasters, thermal detonators, and the good old the E-11 blaster rifle that will be imprecise as usual (in a shy attempt to justify the stormtroopers' lame aim). Of course there will be new weapons, as rocket launchers, explosives and tripbombs, but the real innovation comes as soon as you recover your force powers and your lightsaber as a third person view is applied and the levels will urge you to jump up and down with your jedi powers. Now jump and the saber throw are not force powers to use but are implicit in your actions (meaning you can use force jump as you jump, and launch the lightsaber with the secondary fire button), and the best part is of course the lightsaber combat system. Now you don't have just a couple of clunky moves, now you have a proper combat system where your moves will be determined by any direction key you use and you will learn" three combat styles
recommended: Strong and fast that will allow to deal different damage ranges

During your fights you can also lock you lightsaber against a sith's lightsaber and you have to hit fire as fast as you can to push harder and leave the opponent defenseless for a few second so you can exploit that opening to strike hard.\n\nAnyways this is the only Jedi knight you don't choose light or dark side

Great game- Start off with no, not a lightsaber but a classic E11- Blaster Rifle. The levels are quite puzzling, a challenge for some, breeze for others. Recommend this to Star Wars fans who are up for an adventure. After going through a few puzzling missions, you'll eventually gain force powers and a lightsaber. I'm not going to go any further (spoilers). But the lightsaber battles are great and you will actually use other weapons, so ya don't have to stick with a lightsaber. You can clear enemies in your path with the force (lightning) and throw enemies of edges using force (grip).  And you can swap between 1st and 3rd person(s) wielding any weapon.

Great game for Star Wars fans interested in the Expanded Universe.

reviewText: Of all the Jedi Knight games, I thought this one was the best, both story-wise and in terms of gameplay. As a sequel to Jedi Knight, Jedi Outcast continues the tale of Kyle Katarn, a man whose experience with the Dark Side in Mysteries of the Sith has left him rather jaded with regards to the Force. He comes out a better man for it, though â€“ it is in this game that he established himself as one of my favourite Star Wars characters ever.\n\nNow, Jedi Knight II is a game from the early 00's, so it's obviously a bit dated. The fact that you are a fan of Star Wars suggests, however, that you should be able to look past that... and if you can, I guarantee that you're in for one heck of a treat.

reviewText:
Love this game, have done so since I first set hands on it over 10 years ago. Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast puts you in the head of Kyle Katarn, a Jedi with a conflicted past and uneasy relationship with the force, and takes you through a journey of loss, discovery, gross error and ultimate redemption in the face of a dire threat, marshaled by a Dark Jedi named Dessan, spearheaded by a force of artificially-imbued pseudo-Jedi known as 'Reborn'.

The first few levels of the game are a straight forward first-person shooter with puzzle solving elements and some platforming. This is a very well crafted part of the game with strong weapon play (it is respectable that the game developers put the effort into fully fleshing out both portions of the gameplay - both lightsabers and weapons) if slightly outdated AI. The second level in particular - set in a Coruscant-like city of towering blocks and bottomless pits between them named 'Nar Shaddaa' (also seen in TOR, and possibly Bounty Hunter') - features some genuinely devious puzzles and sniper challenges.

After these portions of the game, the player takes up the mantel of the Jedi once again - with the assistance of a Mark Hamill-voiced Luke Skywalker - and fights through a number of missions of platforming, puzzle solving, and some exquisitely entertaining lightsaber battles and 'boss' encounters.

JKII is a challenging game, long, with well designed levels and graphics that, while ageing, still stand up (and can be modded). Memorable characters, a good story, some twists that are very much in the tradition of the canon and some fantastic cameos by characters from the original Star Wars trilogy all goes together to make this game a must-play.

reviewText:
Game is still fun to play after over 10 years. There are some glitches with Multiplayer, such as freezing within 15-20 seconds of a match. I've never had these problems 10 years ago on CD without Steam. I think if you tweak some of the Graphics settings, then most of the glitches go away. For example, don't choose a resolution higher than your screen, turn steam overlay OFF, turn that EAX" sound option in the game OFF.

Single Player is still awesome. Supposedly there is a full HD remake mod coming out someday called "Reborn".
Multiplayer is still fun
date: but hardly anyone plays anymore. I think i've encountered 6-10 real human players so far. Some of these servers trick you by giving unsual names to bots. Trying new skins and mods is still always fun.\n\nOther than the lack of players and minor
hoursPlayed: this is still my favourite star wars game of all time."

reviewText:
10/10 - dgn

If you're keen on immersion in the Star Wars universe, then play this game in first person on Jedi Master difficulty.
An underrated amount of quality and care went into this game. - Seriously, I barely know half the lightsaber movements, let alone apply them in a battle.

I can keep playing the Single Player campaign once each year, this game is that good. As soon as I start the trial at the academy, I feel the force flowing through me. Becoming a Jedi (via The Valley of the Jedi) is an amazing experience that can only be potrayed through this masterpiece of a game.

All hope is lost of us ever seeing a good Star Wars game like this ever again, thanks to Disney selling the game rights to EA.

Awards:

reviewText: To this date, Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy (and their much different, much older predecessor, Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight) remain two of the best Star Wars games available.  Both based on the old Quake 3 engine, they feature a unique take on lightsaber combat and boast an authentic Original Trilogy feel.  Multiplayer still works (it doesn't rely on developer servers), and can be used online or with LAN buddies.  Still runs stable on Windows 7, tho a few CFG tweaks are needed for modern screen resolutions (thanks, WSGF).  If you're looking for some good Star Wars games, or just some good games in general, don't pass this series up!\n\nI'd leave a similar review for Jedi Academy, but my JA disks haven't worn out yet.  I'm happy to purchase either of these games twice.

reviewText:
Played through the game for the nth time on hardest difficulty so had to leave a review now. I think this game is a must have for every true Star Wars fan. It's an old game so don't expect beautiful graphics. The story is great. Together with the Star Wars setting and iconic music/effects it gives a great feeling.

The lightsabre combat is amazing. It isn't easy though, takes time to master! Even if you think you are a skilled melee fighter by the end of the game, you go online and people will beat you like nothing. Using force powers also really fit into the game, every single force power is useful.

What I didn't like the most is the level design. If you play for the first time, you will get stuck everywhere. Sometimes you need to shoot a crate somewhere to blow a hole in the wall or jump on top of a structure which is not self explanaitory. But either you walk around for hours trying to find the way or go online and check a walkthrough (better option).

The game forces you to use weapons insead of lightsabre lot of times, because annoying snipers are everywhere. The problem on hardest difficulty is the lack of balance, it surely wasn't tested well. There are some very tough fights, the fight with Lando on Nar Shaddaa, where I was pulling my hair after trying for the hundredth time, while the main fights are quite easy. Beating Tavion wasn't much of a challenge and the final boss is way too easy.

All in all a great game with some bad level design, 8/10 would recommend!

reviewText:
Im not sure what to think of this game, when i bought it on release i liked it even if it had some frustrating elements. Such as:
* The map designs are awful and you occasionally get stuck wandering about trying to find your way only to realize that you were suppose to go in a direction that doesnt make any sense at all (appearently i wasnt suppose to walk out on the lenghty bridge that looks like its leading on the right direction, instead you have to jump out of a window in a dark corner).
* Enemy snipers are ridiculously accurate and fast on the trigger even on normal difficulty.
* Scripted ambushes, get used to them.
* Hitting enemies with laser pistols and rifles can be a tedious business. Trying to hit constantly strafing foes with laser lights that travel at the speed of small rodents gets old pretty quickly. Instead I just run in a straight line towards them holding down the fire button. Doesnt sound like an intresting gun fight at all now does it.
* Grenade throwers, they are everywhere. Strangely enough often in tiny rooms.
* Did i hit with my light saber or not? Maybe, who knows. The light saber fights are often just a shiny mess.

So there are alot of frustrating issues with the game, but for some reason i keep getting back to it. I turn it off with a sigh but i still start it a few hours again later. So there is obviously some appeal in it, i dont know what it is though =P

reviewText: Just like the Half-Life series, except star wars. Still can't believe how good this game is for being made in 2003.

One of the first games I ever played, a must have for any Star Wars fan. After 11 years this game is still as amazing as ever with its gameplay and innovative lightsaber/force system. Sure it's starting to show age in terms of graphics but c'mon, that's not what you play the game for. Overall one of the best star wars games, and a nice nostalgia trip if you played it back in the day.

This is such a great game. I remember back when it first came out how amazing it was. It's an FPS where you can also have a lightsaber (it becomes third person for that weapon.) What I remember amazing me when this came out was that the lightsaber actually leaves marks in the wall where you hit it. It was awesome then and is still pretty neat.  I played BioShock: Infinite immediately before Jedi Outcast this time. What struck me was how easy BioShock is compared to this game. In BioShock, all you have to do is push â€œnâ€ and you see where you have to go. This game hss hardcore puzzle solving with no hints in game. It really is amazing the difference between the games. All in all this is a 10/10 for me. I hope this game is playable on future OS as well. As of now it is very playable on Windows 8, and you can even find a fix online to make the resolution look good on modern screen resolutions. Highly recommended.

reviewText: This game series was a classic of mine. Based off the Quake(TM) Engine, the game holds the feelings of the original Quakes, with puzzles and head-scratching paths that make it feel like the game isn't holding your hand the whole time. This game is far more difficult than it's successor, Jedi Academy, which I grew up with. I highly recommend it to Star Wars fans (this whole series, actually). It's a must-have.
The game is great, but I wish I knew how to play online multiplayer. Nothing seems to work :(

Thank Raven for taking this series over, you know, while they were still their own company. Jedi Outcast was an addiction for me for well over a year, with me modding the fudge out of this game and setting up my own epic battles between hundreds of Jedi and Sith every weekend, with hours spent enjoying realistic saber gore. The saber combat was amazing coming off the story-focused prequel, and made the multiplayer an addictive addition (which I totally dominated for months!) to a single-player campaign on the level of the best EU material.

While the level design often remains noticeably, remarkably Jedi Knight quality (read: confusing and maze-like), especially early on before you're able to kick total patoot and forget about level confusion.

Also, Katarn, Our Hero, has a beard, and he fights a Dramatic Reptile. Game of the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed Year.
Best Star Wars game ever! Played it when I was a kid and I still love it!

I look back on the hours I've spent in Jedi Knight 2.

I've played through this story many times and always come back for more. It is, what I consider, the best Star Wars game ever made. The combat is fluid, fun and for its time, innovative - you actually feel like a jedi.

You get caught up in this amazing story that centers around the real Star Wars Universe and come across some very familar characters along the way (no spilers).
Kyle Katarn is also one of the best characters in the universe despite being considered cannon or not.

HE'S STILL CANNON TO ME DAMN IT!

Go for a nostalgia trip and expect to enjoy this tasty romp.

May the force be with you

This game series was a classic of mine. Based off the Quake(TM) Engine, the game holds the feelings of the original Quakes, with puzzles and head-scratching paths that make it feel like the game isn't holding your hand the whole time. This game is far more difficult than it's successor, Jedi Academy, which I grew up with. I highly recommend it to Star Wars fans (this whole series, actually). It's a must-have.

Released in '02, Jedi Knight II improves everything about Dark Forces II:Jedi Knight.
Saber combat is tight and easy to learn, the levels are detailed and long.

When I posted this review in 2012, the multiplayer community was still going strong, and infact, was going through a revitalization. Player numbers were at an all time high in 6 years back then. However, currently, the game's multiplayer scene has vanished due to age. You can still find a couple servers up with dedicated members, but it's no where near populated as it was years ago. Multiplayer is still fun, however, so you should check it out for sure.

With the death of FileFronts main sites, namely Jedi Knight Files, mods and extra content for this game have vanished. There are similar sites, such as massassitemple.net, and JKHub to find salvaged mods from the early days, but there's not much being made now.

At it's core, this is quite possibly the best Star Wars game ever made in terms of lightsaber combat, expanded universe story, and force use. Like the rest of the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight series, this is a must own if you are a Star Wars fan, or if you are looking for an enjoyable Star Wars experience.
Was and, in my opinion, still is the best jedi simulator out there.\n\nEasily one of the best, if not my favourite,  Star Wars games.
I will have a drink in a clean glass.
One of the best star wars games out there.

Wow. This game..... I'm gonna be up front here. Not only do I think this is the greatest Star Wars game, but I think it's the best use of the Star Wars name outside of the original trilogy. What makes this game so special to me? For one, it's a great first-person shooter, with satisfying combat and some really great level design. But what makes this game truly stand out amongst its (inferior) Star Wars-game bretheren is that at some point early in the game, there is a MAJOR change. Well, not really a change, but more of an addition: the Lightsaber and the various Force powers. When these two are introduced, the game goes from very good to just full-blown spectacular. Lightsaber combat & use of Force powers is simply perfect in this game, especially when used in conjunction. It also brings a ton of different ways you can approach combat situations- Should I mind trick the rocket-wielding Trooper to wipe out his squad for me? Push them off the cliff one by one? Or just throw my saber and slash them away mercilessly? Also, your progression of power throughout the game is pefect- your lightsaber ability and Force powers will be FAR more advanced near the end than early on, yet the game will still find creative ways to challenge your combat prowess.  Not to mention, dueling other dark Jedi is an absolute blast, and requires not only good sabering skills, but quick wits to out-think your opponent, and use your Force abilities more wisely than them. The levels are also intricately designed to allow for some fun exploration, with classic Secret Areas being scattered throughout, and there are even some decent puzzles in this game. Not only is the gameplay itself sublime, but the tale of your character, Kyle Katarn, and his return to the ways of the Force is surprisingly well-written. Although cheesy at times, the story does possess an emotional heft at certain moments, and in the end it is quite an enjoyable narrative. Oh, and all this is just covering the single-player portion of the game- there is an awesome multiplayer suite that plays well, and has some really unique gametypes going for it. All in all, I feel that this is one of the most underrated titles out there, and will always be one that I love. In my opinion, it's the best Star Wars game you can possibly find.
Outstanding Star Wars Game

Without making too much of a long review, I have played this game since the day it first came out and I can say that without a doubt  has to be one of the best if not all time games of all time.

This is old-school through and through. In both good and bad.

So what's good about it? It does not hold your hand. It does not restrict your actions or freedom. No QTEs of any description. It is bloody hard at places. I cosider myself a very experienced FPS player, and I've beaten this game earlier several times. But jumping into it on third(out of four) difficulty setting resulted in a pretty challenging playthrough, especially before protagonist's rejedification, when you have to rely on conventional weapons.

Fighting other jedi is just fantastic, and is still an eye candy after all these years. You can hack them with your lightsaber, use force powers, push them off the ledges, and even cheese them with conventional weapons sometimes, which is not an easy feat to accomplish. Even regular stormtroopers strafe and move around, making them very difficult to hit early on, until you get the hang of it.

But all this comes at a price too. Level design is just not very good at times from gameplay perspective. There is quite a bit of platforming, which is exactly as not fun as it sounds. Some environmental puzzles are just too obscure - even having beaten this game earlier I still had to use a walkthrough multiple times. Perhaps I was more patient back in the day... Sometimes you have to do things which are jsut counterintuitive. At one point player has to use force to move a crate to reveal the grate You can use force push and force pull on objects, but this particular crate had to be exactly pulled precisely from the left, it refused to move in any other direction and it made no sense.

Also, there is a special place in hell for aimbot rodians with disruptor rifles.

Still, this is an enjoyable game to play and replay, but if you are new to hardcore old-scool shooters - tread lightly.

P.S. The multiplayer is still alive! I've immediately found several populated servers with <50 ping at 2 A.M.

reviewText:
This is by far one of the greatest star wars games to date. Best know for its advanced lightsaber gameplay mechanics; Jedi Outcast's campaign, which for a new player is about 12-14 hours (8-10 on reply) is a real challenge compared to modern day releases. Some levels require precise gameplay but give you mines, outposts, and city districts to explore, with many hidden treasures.

The games main character, Kyle Katarn, is a well loved character in the star wars universe and personally my favourite character. It is a shame the new films might not use him for a role. Levels are challenging, espically on harder difficulties and show a real sense on progression through the unlocking of new force powers and leveling them up.

While this game has less customisation then it's sequal, Jedi Acadamy, I still argue this is by far the better game. More interesting story, better villian (Deissan is a bad a**) and has more stand out moments, such as the invasion of the Jedi Temple. The soundtrack comes straight from the films and there is only really one section I have had quarels about, Simply because I don't like the AT-ST which you have to pilot.

The multiplayer is also fun and even though many don't play it anymore, you can still take advantage of the game's bot system which was not really matched until Call of Duty: Black Ops combat training mode. There are lots of maps and customisation is great with, saber's powers and character skins and dyes.

Overall a great game and is incredible good value. A classic gamer without having this on their play list is really missing out. 9.8/10

reviewText:
This game has not aged as well as I would've hoped. Cutscenes in particular are as laughable as they are horrifying.

The game doesn't really pick up until you get your lightsaber (2-3 levels in) and even then, it can be tough to deal with until you get more force powers. This is an old PC game, so they expect you to have two fingers stationed over the quick save/quick load keys at all times. Use them often.

I found it more fun to use console cheats to crank my force powers up to max, but even then, this is old school PC first person shooter level design. Expect to get lost in Star-Wars-themed mazes for hours while you look for the one door you haven't gone through yet.

Despite all of my negative comments, I still found the game to have enough charm that I kept coming back to it. But it definitely tested my patience often.

reviewText:
Ladies and gents, the page you are looking at is the final destination of the very first TRUE Star Wars game.
Jedi Outcast is still today regarded as the closest a game has ever gotten to capturing the experience of being a Jedi.

Before the perfectly functional but not-revolutionary sequel Jedi Academy, which pads its gameplay out with gimmicks like duo lightsabers and double-bladed models, this game simply features a rugged, complex hero with a single blue lightsaber burning his way through every hive of scum and villany in the galaxy to seek revenge on the most intimidating Sith Lord to come from the post-Empire era and stop a plot that convieniently involves the generation of dark jedi, providing great deals of fodder for epic saber clashes on levels that still embarass most developers in terms of complexity and depth and still stand with dignity in terms of appearance.
But perhaps the most engaging part of the game are the first few levels, where you begin not as a Jedi but a common Mercenary, Han Solo in all but name, running rings around Stormtroopers by the seat of your own wit.
And that brings me to the best way I can sell you this game: Jedi Outcast is the perfect game incarnation of the original trilogy.

reviewText:
A classic

Jedi Outcast is the third (though officially second) part of the Jedi Knight series. I began playing this after completing and enjoying Jedi:Academy and bit of dark forces.

Story is strong. Following, the protagonist from the previous games, Kyle (former jedi) and Jann (pilot) continuing working for the new republic as mercenaries. As plans back fire, Kyle will be forced to re-unite with the 'force' again in order to seek answers and vengeance. I found the plot better than Jedi: Academy, as it was less vague with a better antagonist and motive behind the player's actions.

Gameplay is good. The beginning sequences of the campaign plays homage to 'Dark forces' with you having no lightsaber and forced to use guns instead. As you progress through the campaign, you will finally get access to the glowing blade as well as force powers. The force powers available include force lightning, heal, push, pull, speed and mind control. You only start off with a few powers which are at level 1. As you play, you will automatically unlock new powers and upgrades. You light saber skills will also upgrade, unlocking more powerfull offensive and defensive moves. Unfortunately, you can't customize you light saber or fighting style (ie two sabers or Darth Maul's one) like in J:A. Some people may find that starting without a lightsaber and forced to use guns for the first few levels, annoying. Another issue may arise from the level design, which by the way well done, but will leave you confused and lost some times (forcing you to use a guide like I did).

There is also a multiplayer mode available. Just like in J:A, there are variety of game modes including capture the flag, deathmatch and duel. You can customise your character and light saber (color and hilt). There a variety of maps to choose from which are mainly inspired by levels in the campaign such as the Yavin temple, while others like the death star are unique. You can play the game with bots or players with a maximum of 16 in total. As of this review there were a few players online.

Graphics are alright. Although they are not as good as J:A, there isn't much difference between them. However, outcast definitely has better detailed models and textures compared to the previous Dark Forces games. I tweaked the game and played in widescreen, which made everything look clearer.

Audio is great. Soundtrack is awesome as usual. Weapons like blasters and light saber slashes, sound as they should. Voice acting of characters are good as well.

If you want to play a star wars game with good combat, story and characters, Jedi: Outcast will not dissapoint.

reviewText:
---------------------------------------------My STAR WARSâ„¢ Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcastâ„¢ Review--------------------
Oh the nostalgia, I remember in the holidays/weekends, I'd used to get up early in the morning and turn on my Xbox (Original) and put in the disk and wait. I remember killing stormtroopers and getting alot of pleasure out of it. I think I remember putting in a cheat which allowed me to dismember the stormtroopers (which was the best part).
-------Story wise----------------
Now I haven't played much of the story nor payed alot of attention. When I was a little kid I still didn't care about it. But I can say if you were to read the comic and payed attention it'll be a good story.
----------Surroundings----------------
Oh this... Now it isn't like the witcher graphics or GTA V but, it's still a good try. From my experience, alot of the levels are just this one big playground to kill stormtroopers or others.
Needless to say. The art style is pretty simple. The 'outside world' is all just black and nothing else. Still pretty good.
------------Puzzles---------------------------
The puzzles are simple but also times can be difficult. I'd find myself going into a walkthrough on just getting to the next bit.
---------------Multiplayer-----------------------------
Now, I don't remember going into multiplayer alot. But when I did, no-one would be on. It's like a desert out there. Even with bots it still felt pretty lonely. I'd always get my next door friend over but we wouldn't have fun.
------------------------------Overall----------------------
I do like the story and/or the Level design and stuff. But to be honest. If you haven't played this as a kid  then don't get it. Honestly people just by even without playing as a kid. But this old game is either for Nostalgia or just killing stormtroopers with the dismember cheat. Well, this is my overall review for this game.
I'm rating it a Yes for Nostalgia.

reviewText:
Initially I gave this game a negative review, but after giving Dark Forces a try and replaying Force Unleashed and then this, I'm feeling a lot more charitable towards it.

While my old criticisms still stand (the lightsaber duels being basically luck-based, a few overpowered enemies (particularly the snipers and the grenade-spamming space goats), and the stealth mission being the absolute worst idea the devs ever had), and while I still think that Jedi Academy has more polished gameplay, Jedi Outcast is still a very well put together installment, and considerably more substantial (Jedi Academy mostly being a series of brief episodes" with full levels marking the main acts).

Interestingly

reviewText:
I personally disliked Jedi Outcast years ago (I played it in 2006 or so for the first time) and after these years I still have mixed feelings about this game.
It's not a good shooter. Compared to Dark Forces 2 (I managed to run it off Steam some time ago) it's bland and irritiating. Heck, even compared to Dark Forces 1 it's lacking, and Dark Forces 1 has an auto-aim. Probably because weapons in this game (except sniper rifle and basic blaster) are so inaccurate and their power feels off it doesn't feel much different from having the auto-aim in the first game in the series. Also, being more of a 3rd person action game, the movement while in 1st person mode will cost you life many times after slipping off the ledge.

Yeah, this game is all about lightsaber â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. But it's hard to recommend Jedi Outcast now, since Jedi Academy is plain better in that matter. While Dark Forces 2 balanced shooter and slasher gameplay pretty well, Jedi Outcast sacrificed shooting in favor of lightsaber â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ (after all these years of terrible lightsabers sounds and their exploitation everywhere I grew to hate lightsabers and everything connected with them). I dunno - compared to Jedi Academy, saber fighting with AI gets my nerves off. Maybe the multiplayer is the reason I had remembered it well, up until I launched it now. While in Jedi Academy I enjoyed almost an every lightsaber fight, in Jedi Outcast I'm willing cut my wrists fighting Reborns or bosses. It's significantly less accurate than Dark Forces 2 saber fighting (and shooting for that matter).

Level design is pretty good. It's not amazing, but it's not a walk down the corridor all the way. The first levels in the game are the best ones, with the exception of Nar Shaddaa (the only level where the shooting is bearable), while the rest of them (â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing Bespin) are just a show-off arenas connected with corridors to force more lightsaber fighting and jumping around every corner. At the end of the day, it's nothing to write home about, and the lack of map is sometimes annoying (the previous games have maps).

And there's the story. It's a typical expanded universe's mania of writing (stuff from there mostly exists solely to make money from sad, exceptional people who can't define themselves without connecting to a commercial diarrhea) rubbish that destroyed the original Star Wars theme,

It's not a bad game, not at all, but compared to every other title in the series - it's an obviously sub-par title which got stuck between genres. This game works best on cheats on, off the campaign and off the multiplayer, messing with force powers, cutting enemies in pieces.

reviewText:
A good, if not particularly elegant, Star Wars game that smooths some of the creases of Jedi Knight, and contains many creases of its own that are subsequently smoothed over in Jedi Outcast. Better graphics and more fluid and varied swordplay are tempered by confusing and unintuitive level design, some cringeworthy animation, and dumb-as-a-post enemy AI. You have to tinker with it to get it to fit widescreen monitors, but overall it's a long and satisfying game that capably pushed the series into the next generation.

But seriously though -  god damn, I'd forgotten how f**king difficult this game is.

reviewText: Best Star Wars game I have ever played. It was a brilliant FPS/TPS at the time, and one of the first that I ever played. Graphics were amazing, the level design is just incredible and of course, the lightsaber battles have yet to be matched in quality. Trust me, this game may be old, but it's the most underrated game I have ever seen. I would totally buy this if it were remastered, but I'll settle for the Steam rerelease.\n\nThe amount of love in this game is fantasic, the levels are long and challenging, the gameplay is still amazing, the multiplayer is dead, but worth finding a game for, and is one of the most satisfying things to kill an enemy with the lightsaber. The first level you use it in is awful admittedly, because who the hell makes the first level with a lightsaber contain enemies that use sniper rifles and grenades? But really, this game has the best lightsaber gameplay in any Star Wars game.

reviewText:
I absolutely could not stop playing this game. Usually I play a game and get bored, then I have to switch to another, but not this one. I just made it to the last level and thought this would be a great time to review without spoilers.  You will die a lot and love it. This has to be the best light saber battle game out there right beside Star Wars Jedi Knight Academy. The graphics are a little out of date but still immerse you into the game.

The story so far is right on spot and has an original feel just like Academy did. The level design is a little crazy because you have to actually figure out how to get places, it's not just a straight line. You have to rely on your senses there is no highlighted or flashing graphics telling you how to progress.

This is one of those games where you have to save every time you take a step. If not a Sith will jump out behind you and end your existence. At one level in the game you come up to a door and when it opens you are scared to **** by Luke Skywalker. I would let him jump down and kill a Stormtrooper again lol.

I recommend this at regular price and on sale, definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Over a decade between playthroughs and it still holds up!

You may find yourself hunting around and back-tracking occasionally in the absence of anything like waypoints on your HUD, but it's still an enjoyable and well put together title after all these years. The game's character movement, physics and melee combat are relatively sophisticated for its age.

At the end of the day, you can't go wrong force-pushing squads of Stormtroopers off ledges while Luke Skywalker force-jumps around the room swinging his lightsaber like a man posessed. Good times.

reviewText:
Outcast is one of the best Star Wars games there is. Knights of the Republic, Tie-Fighter and Battlefront 2 tier.

You're shooting guns, exploring ships and planets and slicing people up. Kyle is one of the best SW EU characters. Music and sounds are up to what you'd expect from Star Wars.

I love the level design, but the 'waterfall' on Yavin IV is straight garbage. AT-ST should have been FPS with better controls, but what can you do? It got the job done, sorta.

Awesome game.

reviewText: Best Star Wars game I have ever played. It was a brilliant FPS/TPS at the time, and one of the first that I ever played. Graphics were amazing, the level design is just incredible and of course, the lightsaber battles have yet to be matched in quality. Trust me, this game may be old, but it's the most underrated game I have ever seen. I would totally buy this if it were remastered, but I'll settle for the Steam rerelease.\n\nThe amount of love in this game is fantasic, the levels are long and challenging, the gameplay is still amazing, the multiplayer is dead, but worth finding a game for, and is one of the most satisfying things to kill an enemy with the lightsaber. The first level you use it in is awful admittedly, because who the hell makes the first level with a lightsaber contain enemies that use sniper rifles and grenades? But really, this game has the best lightsaber gameplay in any Star Wars game.

reviewText:
Being the only jedi in the universe to use dark force powers and guns (at least the only one we know of), you're pretty badass with Kyle Katarn.  SHUT UP STARKILLER, MAYBE YOU SHOULD BE PART OF A GOOD GAME AND NOT AN ANIME LOVER'S RENDERING OF HIS LAST SEIZURE.

Its level design is a million times harder than its sequel, Jedi Academy (mostly because of the fact that to start off the game <SPOILER FOR DARK FORES II> Kyle had put away his lightsaber and tossed in the towel on being a Jedi after nearly falling to the dark side).

Running on the id Engine, it pretty much is an HD DOS shooter now with free mouse movement and full implementation of WASD.  As for its textures, you can see the facial mask on Katarn, I'll say that.  Other than that, the textures and models hold up nicely against newer games still, though some textures are showing their technological age.

It's very well optimized and other than the fact that it's locked in 4:3 aspect (which can be changed if you read this short and helpful guide for giving yourself widescreen), it's perfectly compatible with new systems.  You don't really need widescreen, though, because even then the game looks fine.  If you like it, though, you should definitely consider its sequel Jedi Academy.

As for multiplayer, not many people play it.  However, it is there and does have AI that you could possibly be able to customize.  The AI isn't that bad, but I'd still recommend getting a few LAN buddies or playing online with a friend (though you may need Hamachi, I never tried Internet).

It's very easy to get mods for this game.  You can find all the files in C:\Program Files...\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Outcast.  From there you can go to the folder GameData
date:
then you make a new folder called whatever you want it to be and put the mod(s) files right in the folder.  From the game under options, your mod will now be on the list of mods.

Okay, now back to the topic of graphics: Why haven't newer games tried to accomplish this?  Even if the id Engine 3 didn't have support for normal maps, it still is a very good looking game.  Did you know that your lightsaber has dynamic lighting?  That your lightsaber will also leave streaks and burn lines wherever it touches?  That it has dismemberment/decapitation without blood if you turn it on in the console (also with instructions in a guide)?  This game was high-end.  Other than that, the viewmodels look fine, and there is also a toggle for third person mode.  I turned on an option that automatically goes to third person for any lightsaber combat, and first person for any guns.  This is easy to turn on and extremely useful.

As for gameplay, everything works perfectly, and come on... the game even has a parkour system as long as you've got a good enough force-jump ability!  There are also plenty of weapons, as well as low-light goggles, storable bacta medkits, and more.  Even before the lightsaber, you get this special lightning baton.


If you're wondering about storyline, it takes place just after the rest of the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight games, which is at this point just after the Empire collapsed to the New Republic (after the 6th episode).

You should definitely consider getting this game.  Even if you're not a fan of Star Wars, this altogether an awesome game.

reviewText:
This game is old and a bit dated, but it's still worth it if you are a Star Wars Fan of the original trilogy. Although this game is older than Jedi Academy, this game is in some aspects even better.

+ You play as Kyle Katarn. He is just a great character and he isn't just a boring monk like some other Jedi. I hope he will star in the next movie.
+ This game has some great puzzles. But it's only appealing if you like puzzles. Otherwise they show up way too often and are way to hard.
+ Great variety of different gameplay mechanics. I was impressed what a game this old can offer. There is a stealth mission, you have to use robots and you can awkwardly walk with an AT-ST!
+ The antagonist works.
+ I really liked the final mission with the great soundtrack.
+ the level design sometimes offers different ways to choose from, which was very much appreciated.

- It lasts a while until you get your lightsaber. Although I didn't mind and I understand the importance of character development, other players will be annoyed with this. If this is the case, I recommend you to give Jedi Academy a try.
- Some puzzles are hard. I had to look up the solution of some problems on the internet several times.
- The maps are quit complex and you will sometimes desperately wander around the map in order to find the way to go.  I tried to avoid looking up the solution though and I only used it, if i got too frustrated. :D
- It's sometimes difficult to identify a control panel with a switch from the others without a switch. They look nearly the same. And worse, it's not always clear what the switch was for.

This is only for die hard Star Wars Fans who liked Jedi Academy and wish to see more of this universe. Wait until its on sale though.

reviewText:
I appreciate that you have to play older games with a certain eye, particularly those from the early days of 3D, and in some ways it can be interesting to see what has been lost from that era. Sprawling levels full of secrets, fast movement and twitch based aiming are all sadly mostly gone from the modern shooter. Jedi Knight 2 is a throw back to that era, and it is terrible.

Letâ€™s start with the worst offender - The level design, which is just mind blowingly horrible. The first two levels leave you lightsaberless in a selection of featureless bland, grey corridors fighting stormtroopers that mill around like jackbooted schoolkids. The levels are massive, unintuitive mazes with no map screen, and the game constantly breaks itâ€™s own rules â€“ at one point you have to blow up a barrel to burn out a switch. None of the other barrels in the game up until that point have done anything to switches when they blew up nearby, so why the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ would this one?

The weapons, outside of the lethal glowstick are pretty much universally rubbish, a bunch of unsatisfying weightless guffpumpers, made worse by enemy feedback, or the lack of it â€“ they seem to just absorb fire until they remember to keel over dead. The stormtrooper rifle is at least lore accurate â€“ you wonâ€™t be hitting â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ with it unless at point blank range, and even then itâ€™s touch and go. The grenades are laughably terrible as well, exploding with all the force and thunder of a damp dog fart.

If you grit your teeth through six hours of this, you finally get your lightsaber and some force powers. Things are looking up â€“ you can now cut down fools and reflect blaster shots! The level after your Jedi trial? A city full of narrow walkways and infuriating pixel accurate snipers that canâ€™t be blocked. This is a soul sapping chore, made rage inducing by the god-awful platforming â€“ Kyle Katarn appears to have greased up his shoes, and will fly off a platform at even the slightest prompt. Even more bafflingly, you can prevent this by holding down the use button, necessitating strange hand contortions. Why? What possible reason could the devs have to not have this on at all times? In what situation do you WANT to skid around like youâ€™re moonwalking in a bacon factory?

There are those that will defend the game based on its story. They are wrong. The cutscenes, featuring terrifying Star Wars mannequins as animated by Monty Python, are at least amusing in their incompetence. Kyle Katarn has always been the universeâ€™s most rubbish Jedi (and heâ€™s got stiff competition post prequels), but here heâ€™s almost painfully uninteresting, a scowling, badly animated beard with a rubbish dead girlfriend.

reviewText: I mostly played this game back when it came out and I loved it. Gameplay mechanics, plot and cutscene visuals are all great for the time when this came out. It takes quite some time to get through it and besides combat there are lots of tasks you have to complete which never really become repetitive.\n\nI'd say don't get it for full price (which is 10â‚¬ for me right now) but only because it's so dated already, not because there's any devaluing aspect about the game itself.

reviewText: I loved this game as a kid. Spent hours playing multiplayer maps. Would play until parents made me quit kind of awesome.  Now that I own it again, my relationship with my fiancee may be over. I may play this game until the end of time. Ok, I'm being overly dramatic.\n\nStill, the menus are easy to use, the game is easy to understand. multiplayer jedi duels in its purest, rawest form. if this game was a car, it would be a '70 Charger.

reviewText: Lives up to the nostalgia as well as the mantle of LucasArts (back when they made good games.) Play as Kyle Katarn, the 5th most BA StarWars character of all time as he battles against the Dark Side of the Force and the Imperial Remnant headed by the Dark Lord, Desaan. Rediscover the Power of the Force as Kyle once again enters the Valley of the Jedi, puts on his man-pants and takes care of business. One of (if not) the best StarWars game ever, deserves a heavy recommend for its gameplay, story, character design/development and for holding up in its advanced age. A true treat for any StarWars fan.\n\n9/10 Two hooves up.

reviewText: Lives up to the nostalgia as well as the mantle of LucasArts (back when they made good games.) Play as Kyle Katarn, the 5th most BA StarWars character of all time as he battles against the Dark Side of the Force and the Imperial Remnant headed by the Dark Lord, Desaan. Rediscover the Power of the Force as Kyle once again enters the Valley of the Jedi, puts on his man-pants and takes care of business. One of (if not) the best StarWars game ever, deserves a heavy recommend for its gameplay, story, character design/development and for holding up in its advanced age. A true treat for any StarWars fan.\n\n9/10 Two hooves up.

reviewText:
Dark Forces 1 & 2 are my favorite Star Wars games, ever. As you imagine with the negative raiting, it's with much dismay to say that I can't even bother finishing Dark Forces 3: Jedi Knight 2 (Jedi Outcast).

Before you think that I'm complaining about the monotinous beginning, know that I got 4/5 hours in with getting to Bespin. I got the lightsaber and the force-powers, and even then playing this game felt more of a punishment than a reward.

No matter whatever improvements were made in the Lightsaber gameplay and Force abilities they do not save this game. The level-design is cryptically linear, the story is uninteresting and relies too much on canon, and the game focuses solely on the light-saber combat, making your arsenal worthless.

The Qualities to Enjoy
Light-saber combat in 3rd person is superbly refined with more fluid movement.
Force powers are more conviently selected. (Ex. The Force Jump is just the jump-button held longer.)
Visuals and scenary can still be enjoyable for what they are.
The multiplayer gameplay is very entertaining for what little I played, but I hear that Jedi Academy is where the fans play online with more popularity. (As well as mods.)
The Outcast from Dark Forces
Nothing about this game other than Kyle Katarn is reminiscent of the previous games' quality. It's an entirely different game that looks, sounds and plays the same, but it all a facade for a tech-demo thinking it's an improvement to the series.

That sounds like a lot of nostalgia talking, doesn't it?

Well, no; I can say for certain that the two games are more different than alike because I played them alongside one-another: I got about 4 hours into Jedi Knight 2 before I decided to boot up Jedi Knight 1 for about two hours. (Know that I hadn't played the game for over a year, and I'm sure I do not have that good of a memory).

In about two hours from JK 1, I was already equipped with my light-saber and happily making it through the dam area mixing up my combat style with blasters and the light-saber. By hour two of JK2, I was looking up an IGN wiki guide because I didn't realize there was an explosive barrel unseen to blow the entrance to the next area.

It then occurred to me that no matter how lost I got in JK1, I never recall ever looking up a guide. Because the level-design guided me, subtly, the same way the player is guided in a game like Half-Life where environments and visual cues told this information to the player. (Also, I had a map on me to figure out my location if I ever lost my way.)

Both of those qualities are absent in JK2. Something I cannot but help to attribute to a change of developers from LucasArts to Raven Software during LA's change from making games to licencing them.

In JK2, you have no map, period; no briefing to show the map or an in-game map to help. And far too often you'll have to blow up this wall from a specific corner, to jump into a trash-compactor to get to the other side, or to do something so convuluted it ruins any sense of exploration.

What makes JK2 worse is how it has detached itself from its Doom/Dark Forces roots of exploring out of necessity for healh, items and ammo. You'll typically find everything littered on the floors, especially health and shield-stations. (Not that you'll need a lot of ammo once you get the light-saber.)

Another major change is how the lightsaber is so vital that I think it's to the detriment of the game. Except for the sniper-rifle which is used for those cheap sharp-shooters who can see you a mile away, the game sends enemies at you with large amounts of health that the light-saber becomes essential as an offensive and defensive weapon.

Combine the light-saber with the Force abilities to knock down or disperse enemies--which are no longer unlocked by your choices but automatically unlocked for you--and the game quickly becomes stale by the constant woosh of the lightsaber. (Admittedly, the visceral sound of the lightsaber is the best thing about JK2.)

These changes, combined with the smaller level designs, all serve to disappoint any fan who became fond of the first two games (and expansion) because they sacrifice the complexity of the old games for the sake of graphic and gameplay enhancements.

An Arsenal of One is An Arsenal of None
The thing about JK2 that surprised me the most is how quickly I became tired of using the lightsaber. Far too often I found that running around and slashing through enemies would be the best strategy for winning.

Outside of the Sniper Rifle for those cheap snipers that can spot you a mile away, the weapons you find become a deteriment to you than a benefit. It's interesting how both games have the exact same combat and guns, but small tweaks to the gameplay completely change what is the best playstyle.

If there are tons of enemies, you cannot move around as nimbly as in JK1 (without spamming the Speed ability) to make range combat useful. Also, despite how accurate" the Stormtroopers' fire their weapons
date: the enemy AI simply do not account for you mowing through them with the lightsaber or have enemy types to discourage you running into gunfire.\n\nFor example
recommended: in JK 1 the Probes were typically placed far away or would explode when you destroyed them that taking them out by other means was always the better option. The only enemy that is potentially a hazard when running into are the grenaders
hoursPlayed: which can be easily remedied by using Force Push/Pull.\n\n(The exception being the snipers
voteText: which are so cheap that running past them can sometimes be the better solution for the terrible sniper controls.)\n\nAs much as I love the improved lightsaber combat
helpfulPercent: I think it's another reason why you wont part with it because you can rely on blocking most attacks (not relying as much on your aim like JK1.)\n\nI'm sure had I pushed farther I would have used the rocket-launcher on some enemy groups or bosses
votesHelpful:
but this change goes to show how something similar in concept has been changed without paying attention to what was done before.

Another Star Wars Game That Can't Forget About Star Wars
This is a more subjective criticism
votesTotal: but I hate how much JK2 serves to fall back on canon to make the story interesting. Luke Skywalker
votesFunny: Lando
commentsCount: Bespin
column16: Yavin are all just thrown into Kyle Katarn's story for the sake of giving the plot any interest.\n\nThe original Dark Forces had the right idea: Introduce a beginning that ties into the canon
column17: relate that to the audience with the new character
column18: and then create a new story. Jedi Knight 1 also understood this was the best solution for making a Star Wars game refreshing by having a mention of Skywalker and the story of the Valley of the Jedi as the focus.\n\nJK2 decides to have you wander around Skywalker's Academy as well as talking to him
column19: and then later fighting alongside him with dozens of Dark Jedi (the only reason I may continue some later day.) You have a similar meet-up with Lando.\n\nI would be fine with these fan-services had Katarn's story been given anything interesting. In short
column20: the game gives him another revenge story where he walks along the path of a Jedi/Sith. (Except there is no good/bad ending
column21: something I'm not going to complain about because the good endings were always the real ending.)\n\nThe plot only serves to put him back on the path of a Jedi when he decided to give it up after he was corrupted from the Dark Side. That's the only inclusion of Outcast that I appreciate as it keeps the focus on Katarn
column23:
but I can't help to question if it was for nothing.

Somewhere There's Still Good in Him...
I'm mad that I cannot enjoy this game as other fans. The reinfinements to the gameplay
column25: serve to remind me that if I could look past the game's lacking qualities I could find something to love."
