reviewText:
If you want to ice-skate around pitch black hallways looking for that obscure barrel or button that blends in perfectly with the scenery while enemies peck away at your health with hit-scan weapons and grenades, this is perfect for you.

I honestly can't see the fun in this, usually games play off their strengths and you can overlook the weaknesses, but in this game it plays completely off its weaknesses. You spend the first few hours walking around hallways looking for buttons that blend in with the scenery perfectly, by the time you learn what the button generally looks like they change it, you don't get the lightsaber in these few hours, you just spray wildly at things right infront of you. There's a decent Doom-like progression of weapons which leads you to believe you'll be using them a lot, you won't. I used the pistol and bowcaster once, the E-11 and sniper are the only blaster-type weapons I needed.

Once you get the lightsaber, you will be pumped, you will want to hack/slash and duel, you will want to master it. Too bad, from this moment on you're against bombers who drop a grenade on death and snipers whose shots can't be deflected by the lightsaber, so you'll be sticking with blasters yet again, but atleast you own the lightsaber now. You will also be doing a lot of jumping puzzles, this is absolute hell because your character is on rollerskates and when you land you slide a bit thus falling off platforms is an easy thing to do. Yet there are a number of jumping puzzles in this game, as I said, they're playing off the weaknesses.

The level design is even worse, I ended up watching a walkthrough where the guy doing the walkthrough had to stop to look up a walkthrough. I managed to get up to the waste disposal part before getting too frustrated, I had to blow up a random barrel that could only be shot via a grate and it made me realise I didn't have the patience. there are a lot of trip mines in random places for no other reason than to kill you for not noticing. My first 5 minutes of this game was walking into a store room to instantly blow up, it forces you to save every 5 minutes (each save seems to go to a new file, so have fun with that).

The game supports 2k resolution, yet not 1080p, it hates multiple monitors and I can't change the brightness to actually see what I'm doing. I installed this on my SSD yet it takes 10 seconds to load a save which gets frustrating when you're constantly loading a save before a stupid jump or an encounter with an oddly placed bomber and if you alt-tab it will constantly put itself infront of everything else making the essential task of looking at a walkthrough that much harder.

I can't say the same for the other games I bought in the bundle, but I'd give this one a miss, I've read that there's a forced stealth segment coming up so my hopes of it getting better were severely misguided.

reviewText:
ok so this is a good game, and I am really only refrencing the storyline of the game itself.
The gameplay is outdated and, with a lot of older games, takes a LOT of getting use to.
The AI is that wonderful mix of 'able to dodge your crosshairs while being 100% accuracte'
The game is so old my antrivirus program actually thinks it's a threat to my computer.
The graphics will give you a headache with constant exposure.
The autosave will only happen one in a blue moon so remember to hammer on that F12 every chance you get.

BUT if you can look past it all, tolerate the crashes, the bugs, the insane drawn out 'puzzle' moments (which comes down to just sheer luck sometimes with dodging rockets) this can be a fun game!
Honestly though 'Jedi Academy' did it better. Go watch someone play through this on YouTube, let them endure this game, then buy Jedi Academy and enjoy the game that followed, and improved on the gameplay.

reviewText:
A frustrating game, if you like to die again and again, quick saving avery step of the way then this is the game for you. The game is designed to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you off. Killing storm troopers is a pice of cake, push them pull them, strangle them you name it - they die in a blink of an eye, but when you meet another lightsaber wielder your doomed for failure.

Then there is the level design, running around like an idiot trying to find your way. There is one level that takes the cake, you can not kill a soul or the alarm goes of... and sneaking in this game is not an option.

There are far better Jedi games out there, Knights of the Old Republic 1 and 2 for a start.

When it came to the boss fight, I was totally ticked of by this game and my character was so under powered I gave up and watched a youtube video of it instead.

I personally do not understand the positive reviews of this game. The lightsaber duels are boring as hell, because you feel like a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ for dying every second and when you are fighting storm troopers you pul the guns out of their hands, strangle them one by one, as none of them have guns anymore - just for the pure satisfaction.

Secondly you can not go Sith even though you really want to because the game has â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you of so much and thirdly you have no control of the development of your powers.

Katarn is a moody â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥

reviewText:
I really should have played this game when this was originally published, but now that I've played halfway through the game it starts to repeat itself with everything I really don't like in this game starts to really get annoying including the clumsiness of the protagonist, the lets try this frustrating part for the 100th time kinda progression, all that don't know what to do or where to go next as an example your pilot tells you on one mission that she is landing to that canyon over there and you think to your self where exactly did she land and also the lightsaber duels in the singleplayer could have had a little bit more to it than just randomly hacking with that saber while throwing some force powers at your opponent.

So if you want to know the story of this game I advise you to watch a lets play rather than waste hours of time to hacking and slashing.

Aaand if you are looking for a retro Star Wars game I recommend Jedi Academy, both Battlefronts and also both KOTORs instead, depending on how much force do you want to be included and what kind of a gameplay you prefer.
KOTOR is much like Dragon Age as it's from the same dev. (Not sure if Inquisition is like KOTOR as I have not tried it.)
Battlefront is like Battlefield but more lasers to it.
And Jedi Academy is like this game but far less frustrating (my opinion) and far better game mechanics and force power including force sence which somtimes gives you a hint of what you can do.

But still if you really want to play this game I suggest that you spend a little time checking through the controls especially check where is the quick save/load keys so you don't have to play from that checkpoint which was like 30mins ago and may the force be with you.

This was not the game I was looking for.

reviewText:
After I heard everywhere that Star Wars Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast was amazing, I decided to buy it.
So here was how it started:
A BOOORING cutscene about the valley of the jedi.
Now some gameplay! Fun at first...
Here's one flaw
THE CHECKPOINT PLACEMENT.
I've spent all the hours I have on this game playing the first mission because of how crappy the checkpoint placement is.
My difficulty was on Jedi because it was my first time playing, then I quickly set it over to padawan.

reviewText: I originally bought this game when it came out and have played it through several times in 2002, but what kept this game alive for me year after year was the online multiplayer part and community (though it's really lacking nowadays, tbh). Now I thought I would re-buy this game and not having to use the CD, when I wanted to play jk2 multiplayer (bought the package with lots of star wars game in it), but after installing it through steam, all the shortcuts only open up the singleplayer part of the game, even the jk2mp.exe file start up the singleplayer part of the game. Even in the singleplayer part, the game wouldn't let me play in full screen, even though I set the custom resolution. Something that I was able to do with my CD-version/installation of the game.\nSo would I recommend this game; sure, if you're playing for the first time and you're a beginner to the singleplayer game and don't mind playing in windowsmode, but as for an old gamer of the game, that wants to play multiplayer, no, since it's not working through the steam-version of the software. Which I am mostly for doing nowadays with jk2.

reviewText:
I kept hearing about how Jedi Outcast is far superior to Jedi Academy, and since I loved last Jedi Knight game and completed it multiple times, I decided to give this one a go, especially since it was already sitting in my library after I bought a bundle.
This game has one of the worst openings to a single player campaign I've seen
First level in a nutshell:
lack of a solid narrative hook
extremely generic base, corridor-ridden level design
one horrendously inaccurate weapon to use throughout
series of mind-numbingly boring button pushing-based  objectives
terrible platforming (WHY ON EARTH IS KYLE SLIDING AFTER EVERY SINGLE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ STEP HE MAKES)
idiotically cryptic puzzles (shooting an exploding box that destroys a switch which in turn causes the doors to open? Who came up with that?)
two types of extremely dull enemies
WHERE IS MY LIGHTSTABER GODDAMMITI've heard that it gets better past a certain point and I believe that, but honestly the beginning did all it could to discourage me from trying to progress this far, so I have no intention to continue playing this game. Maybe I'll finish it when I feel like driving myself mad again with constant sliding off the ledges and shooting waves of braindead AI with an unimpressive pea shooter, but based on what I've seen I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who wants more than  just a slice of nostalgia out of it.

reviewText:
Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast is a classic game with fun combat and challenging puzzles for you to work through. That said, everything else (including the puzzles) can be bull**** and downright stupid at times. On some missions it will give you more items and health and armour than you will need, on others, the opposite. Unlike other puzzlers of the time, this games puzzles are unclear, there is never a straight path or solid answer. Also, sidenote, you have to go through 3 chapters to get your light sabre and force powers. 3!!! You know, they say three is the magic number, but in this case, it just f**ken isn't. Combat is repetative, your light sabre feels more like a wooden stick than a focused plasma beam, normal is next to impossible (there is no way I am trying the other difficulties. No. Way), story is reasonably good but is overshadowed by the sheer bull**** of the gameplay. Apart from that, fighting your way through levels with either a blaster or light sabre is really fun.
To anyone trying to get into the Star Wars line of games, don't start with this one. It's not quite Dark Souls level of punishing but its reasonably close. Wait until it is on sale, if you have your heart set on getting this game.
I can only truly recommend this to true fans of the Star Wars genre. And if you can look past all the layers of 'F**K YOU' on top, you may even enjoy this game.
But for anyone else, this is a miss. Watch a playthough on youtube if you really must know the story, but please don't go though the trauma that is this game. Believe me. Dark Souls or Bloodborne are more rewarding experiences than this game.
Final verdict: Fun enough for a while, but if you want to play for any long period of time, familiarise yourself with how to cheat in-game (because some of the levels are so close to being incomplete that it would litterally take you an hour to get through it legitly). Don't play if you are a first to Star Wars games. Start with something like Battlefront (new or old) or force unleashed.
Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast A.K.A. ThereAreEasierWaysToHurtYourself the Game

reviewText:
The GoodThis is the first Star Wars game with proper lightsaber combat. You twist, you turn, you almost feel as if the saber is an extension of kyle's body. You block shots with it, you lop body parts off - it's nearly perfect. Sadly, you don't get it until a couple of missions in, but the saber shenangians are the best part of this game.

Multiplayer, when anyone uses it, is a blast, but you're better served by the (misleadingly named) Jedi Knight Academy, which is actually a sequel to this game.

Headshotting stormtroopers never gets old, neither does doing the same with the mouthy die rebel scum" blackshirts.

reviewText:
Out of all the original Dark Forces/Jedi Knight games, this entry is the first to be even remotely playable in today's age.

There are still some faults. The blasters seem to shoot just a bit too slow so your targets very often outrun your blaster fire. A lack of objective markers, a commonplace feature in today's games, are also painfully absent. There is a lot of moving back and forth trying to find switches and a lot of repeated corridors in each level.

Despite the age, if you are a Star Wars fan, the story itself is actually pretty decent and saves this title from being a totally poor experience.

5/10 Mediocre""

reviewText: Let me first say that I tried to love Jedi Outcast the same way I love Jedi Academy. But too many things were off.\nThe story is ok. I think that Raven was trying for a ragequit-type game, where the more you died, the more you became aware of. Did not appreciate. If it were as good as Dark Souls II, then maybe.\nCombat is not as good as Jedi Academy; only good thing about this game's combat, is you have a cheat for massive dismemberment. I believe that's very wise. From my personal experience though, this game didn't make it.

reviewText:
Working my way through the Jedi Knight series (Dark Forces, Jedi Knight, Mysteries of the Sith - all played back to back in a couple of days) and finally gotten around to playing Jedi Knight II for the very first time. Skipped it back in the day for reasons I don't recall (The Prequel-trilogy is involved, possibly). And I think, I haven't missed much.

After the glorious masterpieces that are Dark Forces and the original Jedi Knight, Jedi Outcast is a pretty severe disappointment in comparison.

First of all: the basic story of the game feels like bad fan fiction. It's like merging storylines of the first games and adding a whole bunch of idiotic, one-dimensional original characters nobody cares about. Especially Desann is incredibly poorly done and one of the lamest Star Wars villain ever (also makes for a pitiful final boss) and I was constantly thinking about that Star Fox Adventure game when I saw him. The whole story also isn't engaging or told in a way that I give a damn - quite the departure from Dark Forces and Jedi Knight, which both managed to keep my interest going thanks to some quality cutscenes, bits of narrative that I was actually looking forward to see. Jedi Outcast goes on and on about meaningless â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to cover up that you are about to actually do meaningless â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and presents that in some of the stiffest ingame cutscenes I have ever seen. There is never any real tension or drama, it's really not compelling because you are not attached to any of the characters - instead they rely on cameos by Luke or Lando to win you over. They also screwed with the characters themselves, particularly Kyle and Jan have changed personalities and are nothing like their Dark Forces I&II counterparts, particularly Jan's role got reduced from badass fighter pilot to damsel in distress. Weak and disappointing.

The mission design ties into this - Dark Forces and Jedi Knight had several objectives per Mission - once the Level is complete, scenery and objectives change. This helped keeping things fresh. Jedi Outcast drags on and on in each and every scenario. You are basically playing just one mission, but it feels it's like 3-5 levels of the same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ before the textures slightly change. It gets very samey, very quickly. The objectives themselves are also very boring - there is never anything clever about the mission goals or the areas they are in. It's mostly just flipping switches and grabbing keys, hopefully not missing that one grate that is out of the way and allows access to some random â™¥â™¥â™¥ vent that will possibly lead you to a room that you don't even know existed.

And that leads us to my main problem with the game. The map design is unbelievably bad compared to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight. There is just no flow to any of this - Jedi Knight in particular would lead you to areas and you would get an idea how things are connected and rooms are located relative to your position, levels themselves felt like their was some logic behind them. It also didn't went out of it's way to confuse you (most of the times, anyway) and rooms had distinct layouts and textures to mark them as important as well as help you navigate the more complex structures. Jedi Outcast almost lacks all of that. I got stuck in several areas because I missed near impossibly to see grates or small tunnels (examples include a walkway between elevator shafts, several grates in various off-track small rooms in areas I had already visited and a particular underwater tunnel on Yavin IV).  There is a lot of back tracking involved too, and several occasions where you have access to several areas but lack the information regarding the current problem and what you might be looking for (which gets worse, when certain things are scripted and throw you off completely because you might have tried X but tried it before it was actually ment to be done). It is all rather limiting and I never felt really smart or good about it when I finally figured out what to do or what I had missed - because a lot of it was just luck and running in circles instead of actually understanding the map (something that both Dark Forces and Jedi Knight managed to do). As such, the thing I got the most fun out of in the earlier games, was the reason for much frustration in this game - it's just not fun exploring these levels (especially not since they limit your force powers early on - you get to see and play what they want you to see and play and that's that).

Finally, movement and combat - let me say this: I can imagine that this game is a blast in multiplayer. However, I only bothered with the campaign and I am not convinced. First of all, the movement is super-floaty, more so than in the prequels. Navigating certain ledges was a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥. And don't get me started on Force Jumping and narrow ledges or platforms - for some reason Kyle would bounce of like a pinball when hitting obstacles or the ceiling, making him miss crucial jumps and resulting in joyless quicksave/quickload marathons until I got it right (entering that Rogue Squadron code in the communication array was a real pain in that regard). They also ruined Force Speed. It should be called Force SlowMotion instead. Maybe the wanted to pull some Matrix-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off with that one, but the changed behaviour of that particular force power made one of my favourite non-combat abilities next to useless. You don't really run faster during the majority of the game (if you do, it certainly didn't feel or look that way). Pointless.  Saber Throw is another thing I didn't get quite right - no idea why, but it took me 60 tries during the initial training to cut some stupid ropes, eventhough the lightsaber was clearly cutting through the rope. It would later do some odd â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ as well and be a somewhat imprecise tool to work with. Not cool (or fun).

Don't get me wrong though, lightsaber combat and force powers are the sole reason you don uninstall this game right away - with added realistic lightsaber combat" and "dismemberment" there is plenty of entertainment to be had when force pulling enemies and cutting them in half mid-air
date: decapitating and cutting of limbs as you slash through rows of alien scum and storm troopers or knocking the poor â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥s off their feet and see them squirm on the ground as they try to get up when you just slash down and end their miserable existence forever. In reality however
recommended: most battles ended up being a clickfest and all the tools
hoursPlayed: toys and styles you get weren't half as effective as just mashing away. Though

reviewText:
3d crosshairs in a 1st person game, causing your laser shots to hit walls or ledges while the enemy gets a clear head shot of you.

If you die an load the saved game film you saved in main menu it loads that one.
If you die an hit F9 to load your quicksave it loads that one.
If you die an click the mouse button it loads the checkpoint save. some levels it loads back at the start forcing you to watch the cutscene over an over before you can load your old save.
This story is cheesy an lame.
Imagine your reading a comic book an you cut up all the pictures an put them together this would be the result.

reviewText:
For what it is worth, I never got around to playing this game back in the day.. Played Dark Forces, Jedi Knight I, and Jedi Knight III. I've heard great things about it, but... it's really broken on modern machines. Like, entirely broken, unable to function properly if you have certain configurations, and impossible to fix. The game is clunky, likes to crash, doesn't deal with widescreen well, and after a few hours of trying to get it to cooperate cleanly, I gave up. I know there is a quality FPS experience to be had here, but I don't happen to have a copy of XP with an older computer laying around.

I've seen people get the game running, and I know there are guides to get it running cleanly, but I never quite got around to trying to make it work, despite following PCGamingWiki, steam forums, and other sources of information. Did a few .ini things, played with some config files, tried unofficial patches, and then I eventually gave up after it crashed when I opened a door.

I came to find out that It doesn't work, period, if you have a newer AMD card with newer drivers (Catalsyt 13.2 or higher), no matter what you do. It doesn't like to cooperate with multi-cored systems. If you try to play it in widescreen, the FOV will get messed up, and if you try to adjust the FOV, you'll crash randomly. If you try to rebind keys, you might end up with a white screen. If you try to run it in a compatibility mode, it'll either work fine (If you have an NVIDIA card) or it'll hard-lock your computer.

If you happen to have an older laptop laying around, or an old desktop for whatever reason, you should be fine. If you have an NVIDIA GPU rather than an AMD GPU, you should also be okay, I think. I can't personally test it. I do sincerely wish I could play it, but I can't recommend it in the state it is in. It's an old game that doesn't want to work properly, unfortunately. Every other Jedi Knight game plays relatively well, but this one just doesn't like to work... Although Dark Forces 2 likes to run in hyperspeed sometimes. But, that's for another review.

reviewText:
(EDIT: I was under the apparently mistaken impression that Jedi Academy came first. That was a mistake on my part when I made a comparison at one point.)

(EDIT 2: I have posted a video at the bottom that very briefly demonstrates the shifting position of the crosshair.)

It's time to face an uncomfortable truth: no game is perfect. I tried as hard as I could to enjoy Jedi Outcast, and I tried more than once. It's unfortunate, but if you are curious about what problems this game might have, you are about to find them all listed in one place.

One of my first irritations was trying to aim. Your reticle does not stay in the center of the screen: it shifts between the center and the lower right corner depending on the distance of your target. This greatly complicates aiming. Many enemies move around wildly, and your weapons have very slow moving projectiles that usually don't do much damage unless you can get one of those exceptionally tricky headshots. Both you and your target will be moving, so when you combine that with the shifting reticle and slow projectiles, hitting anything at all is an extreme challenge. I have often missed targets at nearly point blank range because the reticle was never where I expected it to be. Bear in mind that you will be shooting for the first large chunk of the game.

One of the most appealling aspects of the game is lightsaber combat. And I found that to be little more fun than shooting. The very first level after you get your lightsaber pits you against snipers -which can't be blocked with your lightsaber- and grenadiers -which your lightsaber not only doesn't protect you against, but I remember it actually detonating the grenades. Timing your swings is tricky, so you might take a shot before you actually kill your target.

And then there is lightsaber vs lightsaber combat. And I was never able to figure that out. (This coming from a lover of Dark Messiah of Might and Magic and Severence: Blade of Darkness.) The Jedi Outcast tries to replicate the look of (highly correographed) lightsaber combat in the movies, and what we get is hard to read. What I would end up doing was trying to always keep the enemy in front of me and keep using force heal. By the way, do you remember those attacks your lightsaber won't protect you from? Like explosives and sniper shots? Enemies with lightsabers are immune to such attacks from you.

Force powers try to spice combat up. But gone are force choke, force drain, and other useful abilities from Jedi Acadamy. (Not to mention the ability to immediately level up your force heal and skip the very worst levels.) In fact, you get less combos in general than you did in Jedi Academy.

Jedi Outcast features the most monumentally confusing level design I have ever seen. It is clear that none of the levels were designed to be like a place that would have had an actual function for actual people before your character shows up. Rather, levels tend to be slightly abstract. One problem is that there are often several similar rooms copied and pasted together, making environments more confusing and repetitive. Jedi Outcast delights in making it unclear what you have to do to progress through the game. I would literally get stuck for 30 minutes and then achieve progress only by shooting a random thing out of my frustration or boredom. There were usually no visual cues at all that I was supposed to shoot said thing, and these incidents happened many times. I have said before that if Valve designed these levels, there would be honorable suicides taking place.

And now for the most frustrating mechanic by far in the game, the mandatory stealth section. If one enemy sees you and presses an alarm, you immediately get a cutscene of Mr. Katarn getting executed. There was literally no reason that I couldn't have sliced out everyone's nipples except the game wanting to pis me off. This section contains the type of hyperlinear gameplay executing the player for not guessing what specific thing they had to do to avoid execution that frustrates me in modern military shooter campaigns. The elephant in this particular room is that stealth mechanics don't really exist in Jedi Outcast. As Kyle announced the beggining of the mandatory stealth section, my already high frustration immediately spiked yet higher. At my first feel of this section, I immediately decided that the game had tested my patience in too many other ways, so I cheated past that part in the hope that the game would begin to get fun after that.

It never did. I reached a point where I fought three lightsaber wielding enemies simultaneously, and I gave up. I'm pretty sure the game was not going to get better after that point, and even if it did it would be far too late for that.

Shooting is broken, lightsaber combat is broken, and level design is broken. What is left? Storyline? First off, the enjoyability of a game's story is always going to be bottlenecked by the quality of the gameplay because you must play the game to progress through the story. Ignoring that, what is the story? That joke of a leftover empire does things, and we contrive a way to have an army of red lightsaber wielders. Just like in Jedi Academy. And this constantly contriving armies of red lightsaber wielders in Star Wars games rings a bit as B.S.

Every time I try to play it again, I always rediscover frustrations that I hadn't quite commited to memory; there are too many for me to remember all of them. I literally consider Jedi Outcast to be the worst first person shooter I have ever played. (Haven't played Revelations 2012, Rogue Warrior, or Garry's Incident mind you.)

Now, the vast majority of players say this game is awesome, and it has nearly a top tier metacritc score. For those reasons, I can't guarantee that you will hate this game like I do. But if you do pick up Jedi Outcast and find it to be one of your most frustrating experiences in gaming, I just want you to know that I called it.

Here's that wierd thing the crosshair does:

reviewText:
There are two main reasons why I don't recommend this game.

The first is the level design is very poor. Half the time you will have no idea what to do or how to do it because the game does such a poor job of actually telling you what to do. I don't want the game to hand hold me or making it obvious, but it would be nice if the game had more clear direction of what to do. You will need a walkthrough to help you with some of the levels.

The second reason is the game is frustrating. You will die many cheap deaths. Saving and Reloading seems to be the most important Jedi trick in this game.

reviewText: This game really meant something in my childhood, and now that I own the entire Jedi Knight collection feels as a fulfill of my entire games collection.\n\nThey just don't make games like this nowadays...

What is it about Jedi Outcast that makes it worth revisiting 13 years on (and counting)?

Its predecessor, Dark Forces II, was the last great Star Wars title to be developed in house by LucasArts, at a time when the studio was just at the peak of its creative powers and not yet in decline.  We might even remember DFII as the best shooter of the 1990s, were it not for a little game by Valve that came out just over a year later in 1998.

Of course, 4.5 years is an eternity in gaming.  By the time Jedi Outcast hit market in 2002, LucasArts' catchet had taken some major hits, thanks to post-Episode I Star Wars titles that were lazy cash grabs at worst (Jedi Power Battles) or disappointing failures at best (*cough*Force Commander*cough*).  Jedi Outcast was developed by a third party, Raven Software, using the Quake III engine; gone are the quirks and charms of the proprietary engines that powered the earlier games in the Dark Forces series.  Moreover, there's a definite emphasis on straight-up action, rather than the vertiginous, puzzle-filled vibe of the first two titles.

So why is this game so much damn fun?

Although JO takes a while to hit the ground running with its blaster-only prologue missions, there's an immensely satisfying payoff once the player begins Jedi training.  If wielding the lightsaber for the first time in JK:DFII was a cool feeling, then in JO it was absolutely mind blowing: there is a level of fluidity, control, and power that is unique to Raven's treatment of the lightsaber here, and it's apparent from the moment you first use it.  One can honestly say, even after all these years, that there has never been an objectively better representation of lightsaber combat in a Star Wars game,

And the Force powers?  While some players will miss JK:DFII's RPG-lite system, which allowed one to invest in some powers instead of others, it has to be said that Raven took an interesting approach here: not only are most of the iconic powers retained (push, pull, jump, speed, choke, lightning, etc.), but the leveling is handled so discreetly that it's hard not to be impressed by how POWERFUL you really are late in the game -- and, wow, is it a treat to take down entire rooms of enemies with nothing but your saber, the Force, and the extremely tight controls you'd expect of a Quake III-powered game.

The story is hardly award winning stuff, but it's conveyed effectively within the gameplay itself.  As a result, JO has a solid momentum that builds in intensity as the game progresses, until the player is continuing on just to see what crazy cool thing they'll get to do next.  (DO, not WATCH; take note, present-day devs.)

Throw in a multiplayer mode that's just about everything you'd want a sabers-and-Force-powers multiplayer experience to be, and there's not much else to say about this game.  Raven might not have made a 1:1 follow-up to the Dark Forces games -- how could they? -- but they more than made up for it by delivering the most exciting Jedi action yet seen in the series, or really any Star Wars title.  I still fire this game up once every several years just to see how it's aged, and each time I'm impressed by how much of a blast it still is.  It's not mere nostalgia at work; it's quality design and honest fun delivered by a talented group of people who set out to capture a very specific kind of action-gaming experience, all while remaining true to the spirit of a classic game series.

If you're a Star Wars fan, or even just a shooter fan looking for something slightly different, this is really one of the most entertaining titles out there.  This game lives up to its pedigree in a big way.

You have definitely won the job of kicking reborn â™¥â™¥â™¥ and you can start work tomorrow :)

I rarely write reviews but Jedi Outcast is without a doubt one of my top ten favorite games of all time. Me and a buddy bought this game back in 02'. I had never played any other Jedi knight title prior to Jedi Outcast and as a Star Wars fan I had high expectations. The game did not disappoint, it was, and still is, a fantastic experience. Not only is it a excellent Star Wars narrative but the gameplay is superb too. I loved trying to take out a reborn using the wookie crossbow in 1st person then instantly switching to 3rd person to finish the job with a forcepull and a heavy swing of my lightsaber. As someone who has been a serious pc gamer for over 20 years I hope you'll take my word that this game is worth every penny.

I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).\nI'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. If you're interested in the Jedi Knight games but don't want to play something with extremely dated graphics, then this is my recommended jumping-in point.

The sequel to 1997's Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II, Jedi Outcast provides an adventurous, bold continuation of the series, while staying true to the core exploratory and FPS combat experience that the Dark Forces series has become known for. While the AI of enemies remains mediocre, the sheer visceral nature of the gameplay, particularly the fluid, acutely-controlled lightsaber combat and the brilliant authenticity of the sights and sounds of the Star Wars universe should suck in any player with even a remote interest in the film series, granting a playthrough chock-full of fast-paced, against-the-odds combat that will leave everyone craving more.

In contrast to the standalone expansion pack Mysteries of the Sith, Jedi Outcast's story is relatively concrete. Kyle Katarn, left war of the dark side of the Force, gives up his Jedi powers, remaining a mercenary for the fledging New Republic with his partner, Jan Ors. When Jan is taken from him, however, Kyle returns to Luke Skywalker's Jedi Academy and takes up a lightsaber once more, taking on the Imperial Remnant and uncovering that threatens to overthrow the Republic and crush the fledging New Jedi Order.

If you're looking for an authentic, brilliant Star Wars game, it's hard to recommend anything other than the Jedi Knight series, and this game in particular. Though the Quake 3 engine had indeed aged quite a bit, the game should run relatively well on modern platforms. And hey, if you're eager for more Force-wielding action? Forget The Force Unleashed; pick up Jedi Academy and sink your teeth in.

Far and away the pinnacle of the Dark Forces franchise. Perhaps the best single-player Star Wars game ever. Force powers are still a LITTLE bit clunky but not nearly as bad as in JK. Jedi Outcast is a great game with a great story that somehow retains replayability, all while feeling very Star Warsy. It includes none of the gimmicky cameos or iconic locations of Jedi Academy (which really wasn't awful but certainly not a worthy successor) but still hauls you into the Star Wars galaxy and makes you forget you ever left.

reviewText: Nostalgia

Possibly the best star wars game I've ever played.

The lightsaber player is beautiful, better done than any other game in my opinion. It does take some getting used to but once you get in the groove, everythings great.

Campaign: 4/5 Lacks a LITTLE bit of depth, but it's a star wars game so you should know most things going in.

Multiplayer: 5/5 I can spend countless hours just wittling away at people. Granted mp is kinda dead now, you can find a cult following in a few servers very loyal to the game and the sales should help bring it back a little.

Graphics: 3/5 what do you expect it's an older game, may experience some resolution issues. Run in compatibility mode with XP sp3 and run as administrator for the game folder in /steam/steamapps/common

Sound: 4/5 Quality is great for what it is. Some of the injury sound files get repetitive. Oh well. For it's time, absolutely amazing.

Overall gameplay: 4.8/5 I love this game and would reccomend it to any star wars fan.

A great return to the life and times of Kyle Katarn.  While the level design wasn't quite as good as the first Jedi Knight game, the gameplay certainly was.  Raven did a fantastic job with the lightsabre combat and use of Force powers.  A great game with a decent length and varied gameplay.

The greatest game made with the Q3 engine (after Q3, of course).  And one of the few games to ever get melee combat right in an FPS/TPS.  In fact, it's so good, that once you start using a Saber, you won't care about the other weapons.  The force powers are on steroids from what we saw in the Original Trilogy films, but not nearly as bad as the Unleashed series â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t.  Like many other Q3 engine games, the graphics are still decent.  Oh, this is also one of the few things left in the Star Wars oeuvre (across all media) that is still worth something after the execrable Prequel Trilogy movies.

Wow! Now this game is the one which got me into 3D action games. I was around 10 at the time of the release and I sat for long hours, watching my friend playing this over his shoulder. Then we went across the town to another guy, who had a CD burner, and I got my copy of Jedi Outcast.
Needless to say that I played the game dozen of times, spent a lot of time in multiplayer also and it's one of my top favorites.

Even after all those years I still very appreciate the game design, story and the atmosphere.
Since then, there hasn't been a better FPS/TPS with a lightsaber in my opinion.

This games is brilliant. It is in my top 5 all-time favorite games. This is the game that the Force Unleashed wishes it could be. The Force Unleashed basically stole most of its gameplay elements from Jedi Outcast, simplified them, and made them prettier, but Jedi Outcast is just so much more satisfying. This is an excellent Star Wars game that captures the atmosphere of Star Wars perfectly. The story is great, the gameplay is a ton of fun, and you can choose between using your lightsaber, plenty of guns, as well as your force powers. If you like Star Wars you owe it to yourself to play this game. You'll love it.

Like many other Q3 engine games, the graphics are still decent. I haven't been a fan of the Star Wars Jedi Knight series so far, but this one is actually alright. The lightsaber combat in this one is much more satisfying and a little more straightforward than Star Wars Jedi Knight: Mysteries of The Sith . The force powers are also a lot easier to use and tend to be more useful (except for Force Jump, which was excellent in the previous game). The use of an Unreal engine for this game makes it a lot faster, the pace of combat is what you might expect from most shooters and the only thing that's really slow is throwing your lightsaber. Not bad. ***

To my mind, SW-JK2 is the by far best Star Wars Game that ever has been released. If you have to decide between JK2 and Force Unleashed, choose JK2. it is far ahead. Generally all JK games are awesome just because they are the only SW games in that you can actually feel like a jedi. You can use all desirable force abilities and light-sabre skills to pave your way through the amazing story of this game, which includes some pretty nice turns and swifts and a quite sympathetic protagonist. Of course, due to its age, the game leaks in terms of graphics, but you'll be able to overlook it, just as I did.

If you really want to have a good sequel to Return of the Jedi" the entire JK-set sure is an good investment. ^^

I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).\nI'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. If you're interested in the Jedi Knight games but don't want to play something with extremely dated graphics, then this is my recommended jumping-in point.

Understand one thing before you play this game: the early game sucks.  You don't have your lightsaber, you don't have force powers, and the levels are labyrinthine at times, requiring you to find air ducts and switches in the middle of rooms.  And then you get the lightsaber, and the game throws a thousand snipers at you.  But then...BUT THEN...your force powers get really good.  You start to feel like a truly badass Jedi.  You're hacking your way through hundreds of Stormtroopers, the level designs even out and become slightly more linear (not completely, but enough so you know which way to go), and it just becomes truly fun.  Rough around the edges, but still worth playing today.
Fantasitc story and characters, and still the best light saber combat ive seen.\nMy favorite Star Wars game, and it's sequel is great too.
Worth every penny ~ !!!!!

When Lucas Arts was still Lucas Arts they came out with a series of either good or kindof annoying star wars game.  This is inbetween.  Jedi Outcast is one of those games that will rub you wrong for long periods of time, and be very fun for the rest of the time.  First off, I am good at FPS games and this is a half and half on 1st and 3rd person.  As you will be using both guns and your lightsaber.  I played this game the first time on the 2nd difficulty and I found that it was pretty easy to kill enemies with 2-3 hits from the blaster, its a bit annoying that projectiles are slow and you must time it right but you get used to it.  What I cant get used to is the overpowerment of enemies.  There weapons do way to much damage, even utilizing your force powers like speed they still do lots of damage to you and not in the good way.  Also the lightsaber fighting mechanics are not that great.  Kyle acts like the lightsabor is as heavy as a claymore when its supposed to be a very lite weapon, so hes basically swinging it around uncontrollably and slow.  And enemy lightsabors do more damage to you than yours does to them.  Dont try to tell me otherwise I looked in the games files and thats how it actually is.  So I found fighting enemy jedi a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥.  However I will say that this game is saved by its lengthy time to finish (19hrs for me on blind run), and the fact that most of your force powers are very good.  Although I dont like how you must use them or else they wont level up, and I know thats how most games work but its not done very well here.  The game also exceeds in being a good fps espiacially for the time.  Your weapons do very good damage most enemies taking only about 4 hits to die.


So is it a good fps game?   â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ NO, its decent but I know it could have been balanced a bit better.
So is it a good Lightsaber game?  ALSO â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ NO, Im sorry but the fighting mechanics for the lightsaber (only against enemy jedi) was just to challenging.
So is it a good star wars game?  Yes it is, its one of the best out there and I recommend any fan to play this game, its well worth a playthrough.  I just wish they did not overpower enemy damage to you.  Dont get me wrong I like it when enemy weapons do a good amount of damage, but this game fails at it.

This game is a lot of fun. The gameplay is smooth, the storyline and exposition is good, and the whole thing is an enjoyable experience from the get-go. Also, it works great on my Win8 machine, which is not to be taken for granted with some of these older games.\n\nI enthusiastically recommend it. Verdict: [ 8 / 10 ]

Even after 12 years this game still holds up. I have never played this game before I bought it on Steam last week (May the 4th sales FTW!) and I can honestly say that even without nostalgia glasses this game is pretty great.

If you're looking for a Star Wars game that lets you experience the power of a Jedi, and KotoR's turn based gameplay while good, didn't give you the experience you were after - look no further. Both Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy are some of the best Jedi games I've ever played.

Also, did I mention there was dismemberment? Holy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ there is. You can chop off hands, arms, heads, legs and bisect them horizontally at the waist, all at once! Killing stormtroopers and sith has never been so fun!

I wrote instructions on how to enable full dismemberment here: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Star_Wars:_Jedi_Knight_II_%E2%80%93_Jedi_Outcast#Enabling_full_dismemberment

I highly recommend this game to any Star Wars fan looking for a compelling shooter or jedi action experience.

reviewText:
Jedi Outcast is in my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made, and one of my personal favourite games. Outcast, and its sequel Jedi Academy, have undoubtedly the best lightsaber combat of any Star Wars game. You have fantastic control over the lightsaber, and combined with the excellent selection of force powers and fantastic gun-play, the combat as a whole is extremely satisfying. The story is adequate at best, and the platforming can be a little tricky, but these are the only negatives I can see. The level design is very good too, as it is with the rest of the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight series.

9/10

If you are a Star Wars fan you really should already have this game.

I don't know why they haven't made another game in this series since Academy".  The game starts off as a fps Star Wars game and quickly turns into a lightsaber simulation game.  The saber combat is so good and fluid that you don't want to use the other weapons.  This could be a fault to some players
date: but I love that the most famous weapon in film history has a game that does it justice."

Jedi Outcast is easily one of my favorite Star Wars games. I first played it in 2002 on my step dad's computer when I was about 7, and I never got to beat the game, as the puzzles were too hard for me to figure out then. Of course, there weren't YouTube tutorials/let's plays back then, so you either had to buy a Prima guide or figure it out yourself. Though gamewinners usually had walkthoughs, you had to read through it - no pictures, just words. That got very confusing though, especially when they were around 50 pages per walkthrough, sometimes over 100 pages even.\n\nThe game is played in the first person perspective, though you can switch between third person as desired. You begin out only with a stun baton and a handgun, and you often find new weaponry, including a Lightsaber and Force powers. Each weapon has a secondary fire mode, for example: the handgun has a charge shot, the blaster rifle has a full-auto fire, etc. Each Force power gets upgrades by level progression. You also learn new stances with your Lightsaber, which have different perks - such as faster swings or more powerful swings. By default, your Lightsaber is blue, and the only way to change it is through a cheat. Here's the cheat: hold SHIFT and press ~ then type helpusobi 1" (exactly as I typed

(CONTAINS ONE SPOILER) Is a great game till now and was even better when it came out. So what makes it great? Thats kinda simple:
+Star Wars-like, convincing dialouges which are quite hilarious sometimes
+Balanced Force Powers make you feel like a real Jedi, not like an overpowered demigod (i.e Force Unleashed). The Force is strong in this one though.
+Interesting, though not very logical level design in terms of realism at least
+Its not just a shooter but also includes some riddles/puzzles (if thats not your thing, check the net for solutions)
+Funny, sometimes a bit ridicoulous ragdolls which may cheer you up immensely
+Steer an ATST (ok, its just a short level, but hey, reduce difficulty to zero for one level relaxes the game nicely)
+9/10 People who have given this game a bad review are not blaming the gameplay, but the compatibility issues with win7/mac (I had none so far with win7 and perhaps one should not buy a mac and then complain that games are incompatible)
+Still a better love story than Twilight
+Features mods and some nice MP-modes (like Jedi Master, Holocron, etc)

I'm very aware that one of my most hated reviews is Star Wars: Republic Commando (as it's the only one with three comments that attempt to insult me), but I never flinch when it comes to a game that didn't do well with its gameplay and narrative. I'm sure you know where this is going (especially, since I've got a big thumbs down on my review as it).

Yeah, I didn't really enjoy Jedi Outcast. I mean, I like the lightsaber combat. No, I love it. It's astounding. It's fantastic. It really makes you feel like a Jedi without all the strings attached (like when the blade is made out of plastic). But I don't like everything else around the lightsaber combat and occaisionally polished level design.

For starters, the biggest complaint that I see from many other critics is the incredibly dull first five hours of the game. Yeah, I'm right there with them on that. I actually set the game aside for a couple months (while I actually beat Jedi Academy in that hiatus), just because the level design was so vague and the FPS mechanics so bland and story so thin I couldn't find any enjoyment whatsoever. Even when you get your lightsaber, Nar Shaddaa is an absolute nightmare of level design. However, for some strange reason, once you get to Bespin the level design and fun rocket off high into the sky for the next 7 hours. The story's still garbage, but the level design and fun lightsaber and Jedi-related objectives are really fun and engaging.

I guess I should address my problems with the story. Well, for one, Desann is one of the most boring villains ever. The only thing you could say that's slightly interesting about him, it's that he's reptilian. And sure, the last villian you fight in Jedi Academy wasn't that great, but she functioned more as a conduit for a Bowser-esque final boss that provided an ultimate challenge. Desann had a lot of opportunities to shine, but he's just like every other bland, forgettable villain you've seen before.

The animation is also very wonky in this game. Characters move stiff and interact with each other in very robotic manners (matching their stiff mouth movements perfectly). Near the end, two characters kiss, and it looked like someone pressed them together, forcing them to make lip contact, but they actually had no attraction for each other. Besides that, the story as a whole is pretty samey. Big bad Empire tries to take over the galaxy, Rebels (or New Republic) fights back, become a Jedi, yada, yada, yada...

I prefer Jedi Academy much more than Jedi Outcast, because Academy was tailored around making each level as unique as possible (probably since they knew the story was pretty much the exact same as Jedi Outcast, but with a predictable plot twist near the end), and centered each level around a mechanic or attraction that didn't take up too much time- like fighting with Chewbacca, avoiding a Rancor, or freefalling down caverns to land on small ledges. Jedi Outcast has fewer planets and fewere situations for you to adapt to to get invested more. But the biggest reason I think I'm more apt to play Jedi Academy a second time, would be because for the 10 hours I played Academy I had tons of fun. I had fun for about a fraction of the whole time I played Outcast. It's not a terrible game, that's not what I'm implying. It's just got some massive flaws, that Academy eventually smoothed out.

Jedi Outcast has all the fundamentals of being a good game, and it definitely shows promise in parts, but too much of the game is spent slogging through utterly terrible levels of the worst design imaginable.

First, the pros:

- The lightsaber combat is fantastic, and while it isn't as advanced as in Academy, the game's sequel, I actually had more fun with it here than at any point in Academy. Something about its simplicity feels better. It isn't as flashy, but it has more weight to it.
- The cheat codes are brilliant. By far, the most fun I've had with the game has been spawning 30+ Reborn and engaging in enormous battles, or pitting Luke against 100 Stormtroopers, etc. It's simple, but kind of amazing.
- The game definitely will make you feel like a Jedi doing cool stuff.

Now the cons:

- Godawful level design. Far too often, you'll end up wandering around wondering where the hell to go next. I loathe games that hold my hand and point me in the right direction with giant guide arrows, like I'm a little child, but this game takes it so far to the extreme that it gets infuriating. At the time of writing this, I'm on the last level of the game, where, after getting stuck for about an hour, I realized that the way forward was under dark, solid-toned water (I.E. not clear) and behind a rock wall, which, from above the water, looks exactly like the rest of the environment. Many of the solutions to the player's pathfinding woes are similarly esoteric; you'll get stuck until you notice the tiny two-foot grate on the ceiling, which looks exactly like every other grate, except this one is breakable because... video games. So much of the level design feels less like an intended path and more like you're hunting for secrets. Some people tell me that this is just how games were back in the day, but I know that isn't true. Doom wasn't like this. Neither were Quake, or Thief, or System Shock, or Deus Ex, etc. Jedi Outcast's level design is frequently just obtuse and frustrating, and not fun.
- The random difficulty spikes out of nowhere. I like a good challenge, but a fair few parts in this game are just ridiculous and poorly designed. The second area, Artus Mine, is often even more difficult than much later parts of the game. The Nar Shaddaa Streets sniper-dodging will have you tearing hair out of your head, as they seem to have perfect reflexes, perfect aim, and about three buddies to shred your health at any given time while you hopelessly try to take aim at just one of them. In the second-to-last area of the game, you have a completely unnecessary, unfair and horribly-designed stealth gimmick forced upon you; even though, by this point in the game, you've pretty much incinerated half the Imperial army single-handedly, suddenly Kyle decides that there's one too many enemies on the map, and if any of them see you, it doesn't matter how well you're hidden or how good you are at fighting them, because the game immediately cuts to an arbitrary you lose" cutscene with Kyle getting captured. The Jedi fights throughout the game

There is simply no better Star Wars experience than Jedi Outcast.

No video game has ever better captured the full feeling of being a lightsaber-weilding, blaster-toting, force-using badass.
The story is phenomenal, though it does take a little while to get going. Saber combat is fun, responsive, and stylish. The shooting mechanics are nicely polished as well, with a very nice array of blasters, repeaters, cannons, and others. Each is fun to use, have multiple different firing modes, The only problem? Once you get a hold of your lightsaber, you will never want to use anything else. For the most part, the game allows for it. While tons of games boast the ability to play-how-you-want
date:
this is one of the few that actually lives up to it. Wanna be a dirty little sniper and desintegrate Rodian thugs? Go for it. Wanna use the force to cast countless poor stormtroopers into perfectly-placed death-pits? Ain't nobody stopping you. Wanna just hack every single thing with two legs like it's a really messed-up version of fruit ninja? May the force be with you, you crazy fierfek.

Pros:
-Fun, responsive gameplay.
-Best lightsaber combat in the industry.
-Monstrous amounts of weapons, force powers, and items to collect and utilize.
-Surprisingly responsive AI (enemies will surrender, panic, feign retreat).
-Length single-player campaign.
-Excellent story set in the (sadly no-longer canon) expanded universe.
-Absolutely brilliant multiplayer (which is still somewhat active, but you can always just go it against bots).
-Cheats galore.
-Excellent music taken straight from the films.

Cons:
-Story campaign is a slow starter, some patience is needed.
-The Steam version has a few bugs and issues.
-Graphics are servicable, but somewhat lacking by today's standards.
-Some levels early on are truly difficult, they will test both you patience and skill (remember to quick save often).
-Multiplayer isn't super-active.
-No longer considered canon (which is a damn shame because this one is excellent).

I cannot recommend this game enough.

Play if you enjoy:

-Old-fashioned shooters with an irresponsible amount of weapons and ways to massacre your enemy
-Star Wars
-Third (or first) Person hack-and-slash gameplay
-Free use of force powers in every way you ever wanted
-A lengthy, story-rich singleplayer experience
-A very meaty challenge
-Offline with bots
-Fun

I'm very aware that one of my most hated reviews is Star Wars: Republic Commando (as it's the only one with three comments that attempt to insult me), but I never flinch when it comes to a game that didn't do well with its gameplay and narrative. I'm sure you know where this is going (especially, since I've got a big thumbs down on my review as it).

Yeah, I didn't really enjoy Jedi Outcast. I mean, I like the lightsaber combat. No, I love it. It's astounding. It's fantastic. It really makes you feel like a Jedi without all the strings attached (like when the blade is made out of plastic). But I don't like everything else around the lightsaber combat and occaisionally polished level design.

For starters, the biggest complaint that I see from many other critics is the incredibly dull first five hours of the game. Yeah, I'm right there with them on that. I actually set the game aside for a couple months (while I actually beat Jedi Academy in that hiatus), just because the level design was so vague and the FPS mechanics so bland and story so thin I couldn't find any enjoyment whatsoever. Even when you get your lightsaber, Nar Shaddaa is an absolute nightmare of level design. However, for some strange reason, once you get to Bespin the level design and fun rocket off high into the sky for the next 7 hours. The story's still garbage, but the level design and fun lightsaber and Jedi-related objectives are really fun and engaging.

I guess I should address my problems with the story. Well, for one, Desann is one of the most boring villains ever. The only thing you could say that's slightly interesting about him, it's that he's reptilian. And sure, the last villian you fight in Jedi Academy wasn't that great, but she functioned more as a conduit for a Bowser-esque final boss that provided an ultimate challenge. Desann had a lot of opportunities to shine, but he's just like every other bland, forgettable villain you've seen before.

The animation is also very wonky in this game. Characters move stiff and interact with each other in very robotic manners (matching their stiff mouth movements perfectly). Near the end, two characters kiss, and it looked like someone pressed them together, forcing them to make lip contact, but they actually had no attraction for each other. Besides that, the story as a whole is pretty samey. Big bad Empire tries to take over the galaxy, Rebels (or New Republic) fights back, become a Jedi, yada, yada, yada...

I prefer Jedi Academy much more than Jedi Outcast, because Academy was tailored around making each level as unique as possible (probably since they knew the story was pretty much the exact same as Jedi Outcast, but with a predictable plot twist near the end), and centered each level around a mechanic or attraction that didn't take up too much time- like fighting with Chewbacca, avoiding a Rancor, or freefalling down caverns to land on small ledges. Jedi Outcast has fewer planets and fewere situations for you to adapt to to get invested more. But the biggest reason I think I'm more apt to play Jedi Academy a second time, would be because for the 10 hours I played Academy I had tons of fun. I had fun for about a fraction of the whole time I played Outcast. It's not a terrible game, that's not what I'm implying. It's just got some massive flaws, that Academy eventually smoothed out.

One of the Star Wars games to get close to emulating the authentic feel of the movies, Jedi Outcast was also one of the titles that helped change public perception of SW games from cheap cash-ins to heartfelt, fan-made adventures. This is the game in which you get to hang out with Lando Calrissian on the Millennium Falcon. It's also the game where you drive an AT-ST in a jungle and then get taunted by a dark Jedi with a deep voice in a temple while the throne room theme from Return of the Jedi plays.

It's a very 'Star Wars' experience - its attempts to summon nostalgia for the movies succeed much more than in its predecessors Dark Forces and Jedi Knight, or its sequel Jedi Academy. All of those are quality games in their own right, but Jedi Outcast has Lando in it. It feels effortless.

Outcast is far from perfect - its visuals and choppy lightsaber combat have aged poorly even if its blaster-blasting is still fun. Its plot, for all its Star Wars-y-ness and syruppy nostalgia, is pretty silly (a dinosaur is involved). The nineties/noughties obligatory stealth section and needless keycard hunts are a bit of a pain. But I will be god damned if Lando Calrission isn't right there sat next to you with Billy Dee Williams doing the voice and everything.

A fun adventure that gets its tone just right, while the gameplay varies. Recommended easily for fans of the films (Lando cameos btw), but for people who are after a quality shooter/platformer by modern standards, it's just a blue milk run.
Played this almost daily as a kid, for almost 4 years straight.\n\nBest Star Wars game to date, period.

If you grew up on Star Wars, be it in the original or prequel era, it was probably your dream to somehow adventure across the galaxy as a Jedi. Before game tech allowed it, this dream was mostly reserved for pen-and-paper RPGs, books, and multimedia. When LucasArts decided to create a game about being a Jedi Knight, it was one of my personal favorite decisions they've made. The original Dark Forces took Doom's successful shooter formula and made a Star Wars adventure with the same kind of thrill. The sequel, the first in the Jedi Knight series, was the first in which a lightsaber was introduced. After one expansion for that game, they returned with Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast.\n\nMy childhood was practically built on this series, but this was the game that truly made me a fan for life of the entire series, as well as the whole Star Wars franchise. If you wanted to give this game a name based upon the films, this could have been called Return of Kyle Katarn"

(CONTAINS ONE SPOILER) Is a great game till now and was even better when it came out. So what makes it great? Thats kinda simple:
+Star Wars-like, convincing dialouges which are quite hilarious sometimes
+Balanced Force Powers make you feel like a real Jedi, not like an overpowered demigod (i.e Force Unleashed). The Force is strong in this one though.
+Interesting, though not very logical level design in terms of realism at least
+Its not just a shooter but also includes some riddles/puzzles (if thats not your thing, check the net for solutions)
+Funny, sometimes a bit ridicoulous ragdolls which may cheer you up immensely
+Steer an ATST (ok, its just a short level, but hey, reduce difficulty to zero for one level relaxes the game nicely)
+9/10 People who have given this game a bad review are not blaming the gameplay, but the compatibility issues with win7/mac (I had none so far with win7 and perhaps one should not buy a mac and then complain that games are incompatible)
+Still a better love story than Twilight
+Features mods and some nice MP-modes (like Jedi Master, Holocron, etc)

Jedi Outcast is easily one of my favorite Star Wars games. I first played it in 2002 on my step dad's computer when I was about 7, and I never got to beat the game, as the puzzles were too hard for me to figure out then. Of course, there weren't YouTube tutorials/let's plays back then, so you either had to buy a Prima guide or figure it out yourself. Though gamewinners usually had walkthoughs, you had to read through it - no pictures, just words. That got very confusing though, especially when they were around 50 pages per walkthrough, sometimes over 100 pages even.\n\nThe game is played in the first person perspective, though you can switch between third person as desired. You begin out only with a stun baton and a handgun, and you often find new weaponry, including a Lightsaber and Force powers. Each weapon has a secondary fire mode, for example: the handgun has a charge shot, the blaster rifle has a full-auto fire, etc. Each Force power gets upgrades by level progression. You also learn new stances with your Lightsaber, which have different perks - such as faster swings or more powerful swings. By default, your Lightsaber is blue, and the only way to change it is through a cheat. Here's the cheat: hold SHIFT and press ~ then type helpusobi 1" (exactly as I typed

reviewText:
There is a moment in Jedi Outcast where all of a sudden everything seems to fall into place. Level design, story pacing, game mechanics, sound, difficulty, scale. It's almost an audible click. Or maybe that familiar hum of a lightsaber being switched on.

Whilst the earlier levels are fun in the way that you're blasting Storm Troopers and working out puzzles, they're also a little clunky. Blasters are, paradigmatically, clumsy and random, and this is no lie in this game. You'll often find your shots missing through no fault of your own, leading to awkwardly long (and extremely hard if you're playing on Knight/ Master difficulty!) fire fights that aren't at all satisfying.

But wait it out. Whilst the game survives the first few missions on it's merits, it explodes into excellence once Kyle Katarn rejuvenates his force abilites and retrieves his saber. Suddenly an entirely new set of dimensions are opened up: huge vertical jumps, manipulation of the environment from afar, the slowing of time and the ability to knock your enemies about are not only responsive mechanics, they're incredibly fun to use.

All of that pales in a comparison against the lightsaber battles though. In all honesty it is hard to recall a more enjoyable, tense and dramatic experience than entering a duel with a Reborn. One wrong move and your dead or so badly wounded that the rest of the fight is going to see your opposition on the offensive. To become adept, you have to be agile and tactful at times and understand when to use brute force at others. You'll never forget the time you take on two saber wielding assailants. That's a feeling borne of a great game.

It's the closest thing to a proper progression system that I've ever played, with Kyle regaining his powers as the narrative progresses. Your ascent from novice to warrior-god allows you to feel powerful, but also like you deserve to be there. Like you yourself have mastered the force and lightsaber combat. As a huge Star Wars fan, to me, that sensation is deeply moving.

So yes, I recommend this game. It's one the best games I've ever played, mainly because I can't think of anything (apart from it's sequel Jedi Academy- also excellent) that comes close to it's blending of character and story progression. If you're a Star Wars fan, you owe it to yourself to play through this. If you just want something to become obsessed with and master over time, then you're in for a treat to.

May the force be with you.
Enjoy the single player game and multiplayer , this game is way much better than the new ones!!

reviewText: Every now and then a game comes along and ticks all the boxes. This game (whilst showing its age now) is fun to play, puzzling, action filled and contains everything I would want in a star wars game. ecstatic that it has been released on steam and for all star wars fans who want to play with a lightsaber, there are none finer. absolute bargain.

absolutely LOVE this game!!!\n\n
Like Jedi Academy, but harder.

High difficulty level aside, this is a great First Person Shooter set in the Star Wars universe. Granted the story isn't anything amazing, but it tells you more about the character of Kyle Katarn and how he fits into the Star Wars universe. There may be a few better Star Wars games out there that expand the overall lore (Knights Of The Old Republic), but this game is definitely worth your time, especially at the price it is. Also the chance to feel like a Jedi and a trooper at the same time by wielding a lightsaber and a blaster: Always a plus.\n\nRecommended.
Product received for free\n\nLegendary

Overall Jedi Outcast holds up rather well.  It does show its age with a few things, level design is a bit patchy and frustrating, getting hit with snipers that are impossible to see until they shoot you (one hit death depending on how much shields you have/difficulty level) and there can be 3 snipers lined up to take you out in one spot, so killing one only is pointless.  That's just one example, but generally it's ok.
The lightsaber mechanics are a bit sloppy which I never noticed way back when, but after playing Jedi Academy, which has a weaker story, but it's combat is slightly improved and flows much better than Outcast.  If you combined the often fun Level design and lightsaber mechanics of acadamy into Jedi Outcast, I think you'd have an almost flawless game.  As it is, it's a classic with a few cracks showing.
As a FPS it's good, but not great, hit recognition is VERY random at times.
As a jedi... lightsaber.. thing.. it's good but not great, for reasons just mentioned.
But the story and of course Star wars univers, music etc, are all used very well and lift it up a notch.  Great to see a reasonable 'conclusion' to the story of the character, having followed him since his old days of Dark Forces.
One of the best star wars games for sure, pretty challenging too. I could only imagine something like this with battlefront graphics & physics. Damn you EA!!!

Well, this is THE posterboy star wars game at the time it was released, and It is one of the most memorable experiences i've ever had with a Star Wars game. Among all the games I play in modern times that include Halo 5 and Battlefield 4, this game is the most memorable of them all. Man, I just could'nt believe the stensil shadow engine and physics at that time, throwing troopers around, the quality first person experience, story elements that were technically above the rest at the time, the authentic sound effects, and general pacing of the game. It was just incredible, and to prove that to myself in modern day, I've purchased and installed this game again recently and started playing again. I played this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ on a geforce mx back around 2000! Such fond memories then and now, woohoo! For someone who hasn't played this game back then, it won't have the same meaning. I'm sorry for that. For the few of us that did, let us band together and experience a collective evolution in gaming that really made a difference in the future of 3rd person and 1st person experiences.
JKJO and JKJA are simply the best Jedi games of all time, i hear that respawn entertainment (ex-infinity ward!) is going to make a star wars game now and i hope they will do their best!

Good game. First few missions are pretty boring and once you first get your lightsaber and force powers it is kind of hard. But it gets a lot more fun as you progress. And the multiplayer is super addicting. you can have 16 bots, and ffa on a small map is pretty hectic. overall very fun game.
